PREFACE
         This code of the Village of Minooka, as supplemented, contains
ordinances up to and including ordinance 2025-15, passed 5-27-2025. Ordinances
of the Village adopted after said ordinance supersede the provisions of this
code to the extent that they are in conflict or inconsistent therewith. Consult
the Village office in order to ascertain whether any particular provision of
the code has been amended, superseded or repealed.
                     American Legal Publishing
                     Cincinnati, Ohio
ORDINANCES PENDING REVIEW FOR CODIFICATION
Listed ordinances have been passed, but they are pending review by the
publisher, and they may not amend the code of ordinances. Additionally,
ordinances listed in this section may not show the original ordinances in their
entirety. Please contact the office of the clerk if there are any questions
concerning any listed ordinances.
 
 
ORDINANCE NO.   2024-39
 
AN ORDINANCE AMENDING PROVISIONS OF THE MINOOKA ZONING ORDINANCE REGARDING
ROOFTOP SOLAR FARMS AND VIDEO GAMING  CAFÉ S
______________________________________________________________________________
   WHEREAS, the Corporate Authorities of the Village of Minooka, Will, Grundy,
and Kendall Counties, Illinois, have the authority to adopt ordinances and to
promulgate rules and regulations that pertain to its government and affairs and
protect the public health, safety, and welfare of its citizens; and
   WHEREAS, pursuant to Article 11, Division 13 of the Illinois Municipal Code
(65 ILCS 11-13-1, et seq.) the Corporate Authorities of the Village have
authority to enact zoning ordinances that regulate land use within the Village;
and
   WHEREAS, the Corporate Authorities of the Village previously exercised this
authority, enacting Title 5 (Zoning) of the Minooka Village Code (the “Minooka
Zoning Ordinance”); and
   WHEREAS, the Village previously proposed amendments to the Minooka Zoning
Ordinance that would:
∙   define and allow rooftop solar farms; and
∙   To define video gaming café; and
   WHEREAS, the Proposed Amendment was submitted to the Planning and Zoning
Commission (the “Plan Commission”) for its review and consideration and for the
purposes of holding a public hearing thereon; and
   WHEREAS, the Plan Commission held a public hearing to consider the Proposed
Amendment on August 13, 2024, with notice having been properly given for the
same, and at that time made all findings of fact required by and pursuant to
the Village Code; and
   WHEREAS, the Plan Commission has recommended that the President and Board of
Trustees amend the Minooka Zoning Ordinance as set forth in this Ordinance; and
   WHEREAS, the President and Board of Trustees of the Village hereby approve
and adopt the Plan Commission’s findings of fact and further find and declare
that amending the Minooka Zoning Ordinance as set forth in this Ordinance is in
the best interests of the Village and its citizens.
   NOW THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED BY THE CORPORATE AUTHORITIES OF THE VILLAGE OF
MINOOKA, WILL, GRUNDY, AND KENDALL COUNTIES, ILLINOIS, PURSUANT TO ITS
STATUTORY AUTHORITY, AS FOLLOWS:
   SECTION 1.   The Corporate Authorities hereby find that all of the recitals
contained in the preamble to this Ordinance are true, correct, and complete and
are hereby incorporated by reference hereto and made a part hereof.
SECTION 2.   Title 5 (Zoning), Chapter 2 (Zoning Purpose, Intent, Definitions),
Section 5-2-5 (Definitions) is hereby amended in part to add the underlined
text as follows:
 
 
 
5-2-5: DEFINITIONS
* * *
GROUND-MOUNTED COMMERCIAL SOLAR FARM: A system of solar panels installed on the
ground, rather than on a roof, to convert sunlight into electricity for a
community or building for the purpose of sale or resale. Ground-mounted solar
panels are usually mounted on racks or posts that are anchored to the ground,
and are tilted at an angle to face the sun.
* * *
ROOF-MOUNTED COMMERCIAL SOLAR FARM: A system of solar panels installed in which
the racking, which holds the panels in place and/or the panels themselves are
installed directly on the roof of a commercial or industrial building to
convert sunlight into electricity for a community or building for the purpose
of sale or resale. Panels can be attached to flat or sloping metal, shingle, or
rubber roofs.
* * *
VIDEO GAMING CAFÉ: An establishment for which the primary or major business
focus is video gaming, and the service of alcohol and food is incidental to the
operation of the video gaming terminals
* * *
   SECTION 3.   Title 5 (Zoning), Chapter 5 (Agricultural Districts), Section
5-3-3 (Conditional Permitted Uses), is hereby amended in part to add the
underlined text as follows:
5-5-3: CONDITIONAL PERMITTED USES:
* * *
   B.   Conditional Permitted Uses
* * *
      Commercial Solar Farm (Ground Mounted Only), subject to all rules and
regulations of Chapter 15 (Commercial Solar Farms) of this Title.
* * *
   SECTION 4:   Title 5 (Zoning), Chapter 8 (Manufacturing Districts), Section
5-8-3 (M1 Manufacturing District), is hereby amended in part to add the
underlined text as follows:
5-8-3: M1 MANUFACTURING DISTRICT:
B.   Conditional Permitted Uses:
* * *
   Commercial Solar Farm (Roof Mounted Only), subject to all rules and
regulations of Chapter 15 (Commercial Solar Farms) of this Title.
 
   * * *
   SECTION 5:  Title 5 (Zoning), Chapter 8 (Manufacturing Districts), Section
5-8-4 (M2 Manufacturing District), is hereby amended in part to add the
underlined text as follows:
5-8-4: M2 MANUFACTURING DISTRICT:
   B.   Conditional Permitted Uses
* * *
  Commercial Solar Farm (Roof Mounted Only), subject to all rules and
regulations of Chapter 15 (Commercial Solar Farms) of this Title.
* * *
   SECTION 6.   Title 5 (Zoning), Chapter 15 (COMMERCIAL SOLAR FARMS), Section
5-15-1 (HEIGHT), is hereby amended in part to read as follows:
    5-15-1: HEIGHT:
* * *
A.   Any and all buildings and structures constructed in connection with a
solar energy system are subject to the height limits of the subject zoning
district.
B.   No part of any ground-mounted solar energy system may exceed twenty feet
(20') in height when oriented at maximum tilt.
C.   No part of any roof-mounted solar energy system may exceed a height when
oriented at maximum tilt that is visible from the immediate adjacent public
street, nor exceed the maximum permitted height regulation of the zoning
district.
* * *
SECTION 7.   Title 5 (Zoning), Chapter 15 (COMMERCIAL SOLAR FARMS), Section 5-
15-2 (SETBACKS), is hereby amended in part to add the underlined text as
follows:
    5-15-2: SETBACKS:
* * *
   A.   Any and all buildings and structures constructed in connection with a
solar energy system are subject to the setback regulations of the subject
zoning district.
   B.   Ground-mounted Solar energy systems, excluding fences, are subject to
the following setbacks:
      1.   At least fifty feet (50') from the nearest edge of public right-of-
way; and
      2.   At least fifty feet (50') from every boundary of the parcel(s) of
property on which the solar energy system is constructed, all as depicted on an
approved site plan; and
      3.   At least one hundred fifty feet (150') from the nearest point of the
outside wall of any dwelling unit or occupied residential building, unless
waived by the written consent by each affected property owner.
* * *
SECTION 8.   Title 5 (Zoning), Chapter 15 (COMMERCIAL SOLAR FARMS), Section 5-
15-3 (GLARE), is hereby amended in part to add the underlined text as follows:
    5-15-3: GLARE:
* * *
All solar energy systems, regardless of whether ground or roof mounted, must be
designed, constructed, and sited to minimize glare or reflections on adjacent
properties and roadways and to not interfere with traffic, including air
traffic, or otherwise create a safety hazard. All photovoltaic elements of the
system shall have a nonreflective finish.
* * *
SECTION 9.   Title 5 (Zoning), Chapter 15 (COMMERCIAL SOLAR FARMS), Section 5-
15-4 (SOIL AND GROUND COVER), is hereby amended in part to add the underlined
text as follows:
    5-15-4: SOIL AND GROUND COVER:
* * *
A.   Topsoils shall not be removed from the site during development unless the
removal is expressly approved as part of the conditional use permit.   
B.   Perennial vegetative ground cover must be maintained or established in all
areas where a ground-mounted solar energy system is located. The seed mix
selections for both temporary and long-term mixes shall be determined and
approved as part of the conditional use permit for the facility.
     C.   For ground-mounted solar energy systems, perennial vegetative ground
cover or farm crops must be maintained or established in required setbacks to
prevent erosion and manage run-off.
D.   All solar energy systems must comply with all applicable County storm
water detention and drainage ordinances, as well as all corresponding Village
ordinances. All new impervious surfaces shall be analyzed on a parcel-by-parcel
basis.
* * *
SECTION 10.   Title 5 (Zoning), Chapter 15 (COMMERCIAL SOLAR FARMS), Section 5-
15-5 (SECURITY BARRIER), is hereby amended in part to add the underlined text
as follows:
    5-15-5: SECURITY BARRIER:
* * *
Ground-mounted solar energy systems must be enclosed by perimeter security
fencing or another village-approved barrier with a minimum height of at least
six feet (6') and no more than eight feet (8'). This security barrier may, but
is not required to, be incorporated into any screening requirements of this
Chapter.
* * *
 
SECTION 11.   Title 5 (Zoning), Chapter 15 (COMMERCIAL SOLAR FARMS), Section 5-
15-12 (MONITORING AND MAINTENANCE), is hereby amended in part to read as
follows:
    5-15-12: MONITORING AND MAINTENANCE:
A.   The owner and/or operator of the solar energy system shall be jointly and
severally responsible and liable for maintaining the System, the property on
which the System is located (including all property leased in connection
therewith, even if more extensive than the System itself), and all associated
buildings, structures, and improvements in a safe, sound, and well-maintained
condition according to the highest-applicable industry standards. This
specifically includes, without limitation, painting, grounds keeping (both
inside and outside the fence or security barrier), structural repairs,
maintaining internal access drives, and maintaining the integrity of security
measures. Maintenance and grounds keeping shall include mowing, reseeding, and
weed management practices.
B.   For roof-mounted solar energy systems, maintenance shall include but not
be limited to: periodic inspections and proper roof maintenance.
C.   A written maintenance plan shall be approved by the Village and are
subject to the Village's existing ordinances including the Village’s weed
ordinance.
 
SECTION 12.   Title 5 (Zoning), Chapter 7 (BUSINESS DISTRICTS), Section 5-7-3
(B1 BUSINESS DISTRICT), is hereby amended in part to read as follows:
5-7-3: B1 BUSINESS DISTRICT:
B. CONDITIONAL PERMITTED USES
***
  Commercial Solar Farm (Roof Mounted Only), subject to all rules and
regulations of Chapter 15 (Commercial Solar Farms) of this Title.
 Schools, commercial or trade, including those teaching music, dancing,
business, commercial or technical subjects when operations do not involve
danger of fire and explosion, and objectionable noise, vibration, smoke, dust,
odor, glare, heat or other similar influences.
 Self-service car washes, coin operated, on a lot not less than twenty thousand
(20,000) square feet in area.
  Video gaming cafes.
***
SECTION 13.   Title 5 (Zoning), Chapter 7 (COMMERCIAL DISTRICTS), Section 5-7-
4 (B2 BUSINESS DISTRICT), is hereby amended in part to read as follows:
5-7-4: B2 COMMERCIAL DISTRICT:
B. CONDITIONAL PERMITTED USES
***
     Commercial Solar Farm (Roof Mounted Only), subject to all rules and
regulations of Chapter 15 (Commercial Solar Farms) of this Title.
Theaters, outdoor, provided that vehicular entrance and exit driveways
intersect with a secondary or primary thoroughfare and traffic signal lights or
other means of traffic control are provided. Reservoir parking spaces for
temporary parking of automobiles of patrons awaiting entrance shall be provided
on the lot, in the amount of not less than the number of parking spaces
equivalent to ten percent (10%) of the vehicular capacity of the theater. No
building or structure shall be located nearer than one hundred feet (100') from
a residence district boundary line. Artificial illumination shall be arranged
in such a manner that direct rays of light shall not beam upon adjoining
properties and streets. 
Video gaming cafes.
***
   SECTION 14.   In the event that any provision or provisions, portion or
portions, or clause or clauses of this Ordinance shall be declared to be
invalid or unenforceable by a Court of competent jurisdiction, such
adjudication shall in no way affect or impair the validity or enforceability of
any of the remaining provisions, portions, or clauses of this Ordinance that
may be given effect without such invalid or unenforceable provision or
provisions, portion or portions, or clause or clauses.
   SECTION 15.   That all ordinances, resolutions, motions, or parts thereof,
conflicting with any of the provisions of this Ordinance, are hereby repealed
to the extent of the conflict.
   SECTION 16.   That the Village Clerk is hereby directed to publish this
Ordinance in pamphlet form.
   SECTION 17.   That this Ordinance shall be in full force and effect from and
after its passage, approval and publication in pamphlet form as provided by
law.
 
PRESENTED and passed by the Board of Trustees on a roll call vote on the 27th
of August 2024

ORDINANCE NO. 2025-19
AN ORDINANCE AMENDING TITLE 7, CHAPTER 2, SECTION 5, COLLECTION OF GARBAGE
CHARGES, IN THE VILLAGE OF MINOOKA, WILL COUNTY, GRUNDY COUNTY AND KENDALL
COUNTY, STATE OF ILLINOIS
_______________________________________________________________________
 
   WHEREAS, the President and Board of Trustees of the Village of Minooka, Will
County, Grundy County and Kendall County, Illinois has the authority to adopt
ordinances and to promulgate rules and regulations that pertain to its
government and affairs and protect the public health, safety, and welfare of
its citizens; and
 
   WHEREAS, the Village President and Board of Trustees have determined one
monthly rate for 64 and 96 gallon containers and now wish to hereby codify the
rate change into the Village Ordinances; and
 
   NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED BY THE PRESIDENT AND BY THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES
OF THE VILLAGE OF MINOOKA, WILL COUNTY, GRUNDY COUNTY AND KENDALL COUNTY,
ILLINOIS AS FOLLOWS:
 
   SECTION 1.  The President and Board of Trustees hereby find that all of the
recitals contained in the preamble to this Ordinance are true, correct and
complete and are hereby incorporated by reference herein.
 
   SECTION 2.    That Title 7, Chapter 2, Section 5, Collection of Garbage,
Charges, shall be amended to amend the following subparagraph B per the
attached Exhibit.
 
   SECTION 3 . In the event that any provision or provisions, or portion or
portions of this Ordinance shall be declared to be invalid or unenforceable by
a Court of competent jurisdiction, such adjudication shall in no way affect or
impair the validity or enforceability of any of the remaining provisions or
portions of this Ordinance that may be given effect without such invalid or
unenforceable provision or provisions, portion or portions.
 
   SECTION 4. That all ordinances or parts of ordinances conflicting with any
of the provisions of this Ordinance shall be and the same is hereby repealed.
 
   SECTION 5. That the Village Clerk is hereby directed to publish this
Ordinance in pamphlet form.
 
   SECTION 6.   That this Ordinance shall be in full force and effect from and
after its passage, approval and publication in pamphlet form as provided by
law.
 
   PRESENTED and passed by the Board of Trustees on a roll call vote on the 29
th of July 2025.
 
 
7-2-5: COLLECTION OF GARBAGE, CHARGES:
   A.   There are hereby established charges for the collection of garbage and
refuse from each family residential unit in the village.
   B.   The charge shall be:
 
64 or 96 gallon container
                          2025  28.07
                          2026  29.47
                          2027  30.94
                          2028  32.49
                          2029  34.12
                          2030  35.82
                          2031  37.61
 
 
   C.   The charges shall be billed bimonthly along with the water and sewer
service billings. (Ord. 2014-32, 12-16-2014)
   D.   Provided that sufficient proof is given to the Village annually to
establish that at least one head of household of a residential unit in the
Village is age sixty five (65) or older, the charge for collection of garbage
and refuse shall be reduced by two dollars ($2.00) per month for the
residential unit. (Ord. 2017-29, 11-21-2017)
 
 
 
 
 
 
ORDINANCE NO.   2025-24
 
AN ORDINANCE AMENDING TITLE 7 (HEALTH AND SANITATION), CHAPTER 5 (TREE
PRESERVATION), OF THE VILLAGE OF MINOOKA CODE OF ORDINANCES, WILL, GRUNDY, AND
KENDALL COUNTIES, ILLINOIS
 
   WHEREAS, the Corporate Authorities of the Village of Minooka, Will, Grundy,
and Kendall counties, Illinois, have the authority to adopt ordinances and to
promulgate rules and regulations that pertain to its government and affairs and
protect the public health, safety, and welfare of its citizens; and
 
   WHEREAS, the Corporate Authorities have determined that the urban forest of
the Village of Minooka is a vital natural resource that is integral to the
continued health, safety, and welfare of the Village’s residents; and
 
   WHEREAS, the Corporate Authorities have determined that it is necessary and
expedient to regulate the preservation of trees located on public property, as
set forth in this Ordinance; and
 
   WHEREAS, the Corporate Authorities previously passed ordinances concerning
the preservation of trees; and
 
   WHEREAS, the Corporate Authorities have determined that it is in the best
interests of the Village and its residents to amend Title 7 (Health and
Sanitation), Chapter 5 (Tree Preservation), of the Village of Minooka Code of
Ordinances, as set forth in this Ordinance.
 
   NOW THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED BY THE CORPORATE AUTHORITIES OF THE VILLAGE OF
MINOOKA, WILL, GRUNDY, AND KENDALL COUNTIES, ILLINOIS, PURSUANT TO ITS
STATUTORY AUTHORITY, AS FOLLOWS:
 
   SECTION 1.   The Corporate Authorities hereby find that all of the recitals
contained in the preamble to this Ordinance are true, correct, and complete and
are hereby incorporated by reference hereto and made a part hereof.
 
   SECTION 2.   That Title 7 (Health and Sanitation), Chapter 5 (Tree
Preservation), is amended to add the underlined portions and strike the
stricken portions as follows:
CHAPTER 5
TREE PRESERVATION
SECTION:
7-5-1:    Purpose
7-5-2:    Statement of Value
7-5-1 3:    Definitions
7-5-2 4:    Urban Forest Inventory; Urban Forest Management Plan
7-5-3 5:    Tree Planting
7-5-4 6:    Tree Removal
7-5-5 7:    Damage To Trees
7-5-6 8:    Tree Transplantation
7-5-7 9:    Tree Replacement
7-5-8 10:    Legacy Trees
7-5-9 11:    Site Development On Private Property
7-5-10 12: Conservation Areas/Easements
7-5-13: Tree Preservation and Management During Construction
7-5-11 14: Tree Permits
7-5-12 15:   Civil Enforcement
 
7-5-1: PURPOSE:
To maintain the ecological and economic benefits that trees provide. To
recognize the services and function that trees provide as a collective asset to
the entire community and to state the goals of the Village of Minooka with
respect to the protection, preservation, care and planting of trees. This
ordinance applies to public property and, in specific cases such as site
development, private property.
 
7-5-2: STATEMENT OF VALUE:
The Village of Minooka values trees as infrastructure and recognizes the
benefits that trees provide in the community. Healthy trees improve air quality
by reducing air and noise pollution, regulate climate by providing shade,
regulate stormwater runoff, furnish a habitat for wildlife, provide energy-
savings shade and cooling, and enhance aesthetics and property values.
 
7-5-13: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter:
 
                                   Any person who is licensed or certified in
ARBORIST:                          forestry by the International Society of
                                   Arboriculture or any other substantially
                                   similar organization.
COMMISSION:                        The Forestry Commission of the village.
                                   An area on the ground extending out from the
CRITICAL ROOT ZONE:                trunk of the tree in all directions a
                                   distance of at least one foot (1') for every
                                   inch (1") DBH.
                                   The diameter of the trunk of the tree

                                   ground line.

                                   village.
                                   Any tree located on public property within
                                   the corporate boundaries of the village (i)
LEGACY TREE:                       having a DBH of eighteen inches (18") or
                                   more or (ii) as otherwise designated by
                                   ordinance.
                                   Any proposed change in the use or character
                                   of land, including but not limited to the
SITE DEVELOPMENT:                  construction or replacement of any structure
                                   or improvement thereon, as well as any
                                   activity that requires excavation or grading

                                   Grundy Counties, Illinois.
VILLAGE ARBORIST:                  Any arborist that is employed by the
                                   village.
(Ord. 2019-19, 8-27-2019)
 
 
7-5-24:    URBAN FOREST INVENTORY; URBAN FOREST MANAGEMENT PLAN:
    A.   On or before January 1, 2020, the Superintendent shall conduct an
Urban Forest Inventory for the Village of Minooka, which inventory must be
approved and adopted by the corporate authorities of the village. Once the
Urban Forest Inventory has been completed and adopted by the corporate
authorities of the village, it shall be kept and maintained by the
Superintendent. Thereafter, the Superintendent shall update the Urban Forest
Inventory of the village at least annually, and shall submit the updated
inventory to the corporate authorities of the village for approval and
adoption. The Urban Forest Inventory must include an appraised value for each
tree.
    B.   On or before January 1, 2021, the Commission shall recommend an Urban
Forest Management Plan for the Village of Minooka, which plan must be approved
and adopted by the corporate authorities of the village. Once the Urban Forest
Management Plan has been adopted by the village, the Commission shall review it
at least annually and make any recommendations and proposals for amendments of,
additions to, or deletions from said plan as it may determine to be necessary
from time to time.
    C.   The Urban Forest Management Plan:
       1.   Shall cover a period of at least five (5) years;
       2.   Shall be based upon guidelines published by the American National
Standards Institute from time to time; and
       3.   Must include, at a minimum, the following:
          a.   Tree selection guidelines (including a preferred species list, a
non-preferred species list, and a prohibited species (nuisance and invasive)
list); and
          b.   Tree diversity guidelines; and
          c.   Tree planting guidelines; and
          d.   Tree removal guidelines;
and
          e.   Tree transplantation/translocation guidelines; and
          f.   Tree care and management guidelines; and
          g.   Budgetary and staffing guidelines; and
          h.   Template tree permit application materials. (Ord. 2019-19, 8-27-
2019)
 
7-5-35:    TREE PLANTING:
    A.   It shall be unlawful for any person who is not employed by the village
to plant any tree on any public property within the corporate boundaries of the
village without having first secured a tree permit authorizing such planting.
    B.   Every tree planted within the village must be planted in a manner that
is fully compliant with all applicable guidelines contained in the village's
Urban Forest Management Plan, as amended from time to time.
    C.   No tree permit shall be issued for any planting unless the applicant
submits and the village approves a three (3) year tree maintenance plan that
fully complies with all applicable guidelines of the village's Urban Forest
Management Plan, as amended from time to time.
    D.   Any person that plants a tree without a permit in violation of this
section shall be guilty of a business offense and fined an amount equal to:
       1.   Fifty dollars ($50.00); and
       2.   The actual costs incurred by the village in connection with the
tree so planted (whether for the purposes of removal, replanting, or
remediation).
    Every tree so planted shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 2019-19,
8-27-2019)
E. Tree care, pruning and maintenance must be performed in a manner that is
fully compliant with all applicable guidelines contained in the village's Urban
Forest Management Plan, as amended from time to time.
F. Species restrictions and planting restrictions guidelines are contained in
the village’s Urban Forest Management Plan, as amended from time to time.
 
7-5-46:    TREE REMOVAL:
    A.   It shall be unlawful for any person who is not employed by the village
to remove any tree on any public property within the corporate boundaries of
the village without having first secured a tree permit authorizing such
removal.
    B.   Any tree removed pursuant to a tree permit issued by the village must
be removed in a manner that is fully compliant with all applicable guidelines
contained in the village's Urban Forest Management Plan, as amended from time
to time.
    C.   Any person that intentionally removes a tree without a tree permit in
violation of this section shall be guilty of a business offense and shall be
fined in an amount equal to:
       1.   The appraised value of the tree, as set out in the village's Urban
Forest Inventory, as amended from time to time; and
       2.   The actual costs incurred by the village to replace the tree in
compliance with Section 7-5-7 of this chapter.
    Every tree so removed shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 2019-19,
8-27-2019)
D. Emergency Tree Removal: An exemption may be authorized when a tree, due to
natural circumstances, is dead or irreversibly declining, is deemed to be a
nuisance tree or species, is in danger of falling, creates a line-of-sight
obstruction, or is a health hazard. Such a tree may be removed only after
approval has been granted by the Superintendent.
E. All tree removal, trimming, and pruning conducted by tree care contractors
must comply with the guidelines set forth in the village’s Urban Forest
Management Plan, as amended from time to time.
 
7-5-57:    DAMAGE TO TREES:
    A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to damage any tree located on any
public property within the corporate boundaries of the village. For the
purposes of this section, the word "damage" means any action that has the
direct and natural consequence of causing any permanent loss of function in a
tree, including without limitation: root compaction, root removal, girdling,
soil contamination, topping, canopy removal, bark removal, poisoning, improper
mulching, and any other action that results in the death or irreversible
decline of the tree.
    B.   Any person that damages any tree in violation of this section shall be
guilty of a business offense and shall be fined in an amount equal to:
       1.   The appraised value of the tree, as set out in the village's Urban
Forest Inventory, as amended from time to time; and
       2.   The actual costs incurred by the village to replace the tree in
compliance with Section 7-5-7 of this chapter or else to remediate the damage
done.
    Every tree so damaged shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 2019-19,
8-27-2019)
 
7-5-68:    TREE TRANSPLANTATION:
    A.   It shall be unlawful for any person who is not employed by the village
to transplant any tree on any public property within the corporate boundaries
of the village without having first secured a tree permit authorizing such
transplantation.
    B.   Any tree transplanted pursuant to a tree permit issued by the village
must be removed and replanted in a manner that is fully compliant with all
applicable guidelines contained in the village's Urban Forest Management Plan,
as amended from time to time.
    C.   No tree permit shall be issued for any transplantation unless the
applicant submits and the village approves a three (3) year tree maintenance
plan that fully complies with all applicable guidelines of the village's Urban
Forest Management Plan, as amended from time to time.
    D.    Any person that intentionally transplants a tree without a tree
permit in violation of this section shall be guilty of a business offense and
shall be fined in amount equal to:
       1.   The appraised value of the tree, as set out in the village's Urban
Forest Inventory, as amended from time to time; and
       2.   The actual costs incurred by the village to replace the tree in
compliance with Section 7-5-7 of this chapter.
    Every tree so transplanted shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 2019-
19, 8-27-2019)
 
7-5-79:    TREE REPLACEMENT:
    A.   Every tree selected to replace an existing tree located on any public
property within the corporate boundaries of the village shall be selected from
the village's preferred species list, as amended from time to time.
    B.   Every replacement tree required to be planted pursuant to this chapter
shall be planted in full compliance with Section 7-5-3 of this chapter. (Ord.
2019-19, 8-27-2019)
 
7-5-810:    LEGACY TREES:
    A.   The Superintendent shall keep a list, to be known as the "Legacy Tree
List," of every legacy tree in the Village of Minooka.
    B.   It shall be unlawful for any person other than an employee of the
village to remove, transplant, or damage any legacy tree without a tree permit
approved by a majority vote of corporate authorities of the village.
    C.    No tree permit shall be issued for any planting or transplanting of
any legacy tree unless the applicant submits and the village approves a three
(3) year tree maintenance plan that fully complies with all applicable
guidelines of the village's Urban Forest Management Plan, as amended from time
to time.
    D.   Any person that removes, transplants, or damages any legacy tree in
violation of this section shall be guilty of a business offense and shall be
fined in an amount equal to:
       1.   Five hundred dollars ($500.00); and
       2.   The appraised value of the tree, as set out in the village's Urban
Forest Inventory, as amended from time to time; and
       3.   The actual costs incurred by the village to replace the tree in
compliance with Section 7-5-7 of this chapter or else to remediate the damage
done.
    Every legacy tree removed, transplanted, or damaged in violation of this
section shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 2019-19, 8-27-2019)
 
7-5-911:    SITE DEVELOPMENT ON PRIVATE PROPERTY:
    A.   Any person that wishes to engage in site development on any parcel of
private property in the village must request a site review by a village
arborist if:
       1.   Any work related to the proposed site development will encroach
into the critical root zone of any legacy tree; or
       2.   Any work related to the proposed site development will encroach
into the critical root zone of at least three (3) trees located on public
property; or
       3.   The person is so directed by the Superintendent.
    B.   Within five (5) business days after any person requests a site review,
a village arborist must conduct an inspection of the site in question and make
a determination whether the proposed site development is likely to have any
negative impact on any tree located on public property.
       1.   If a village arborist conducts a site inspection as required by
this section and determines that the proposed site development is unlikely to
have any negative impact on any tree located on the abutting public property,
the village arborist shall render his or her determination in writing to that
effect and deliver a copy of said determination to the person that requested
the site inspection. Thereafter, the site development may thereafter proceed
without any further approvals or actions under this chapter (though nothing in
this section is intended or shall be deemed to release any person from their
obligation to comply with any and all other applicable provisions of this Code
and the person shall still be held liable for any damage caused to any tree on
public property).
       2.   If a village arborist conducts such a site inspection as required
by this section and determines that the proposed site development is likely to
have a negative impact on any tree located on the abutting public property, the
village arborist shall render his or her determination in writing to that
effect and deliver a copy of said determination to the person that requested
the site inspection. Thereafter, the site development may not proceed unless
and until (i) the owner of the property in question submits a tree preservation
plan to the village and (ii) the village approves said tree preservation plan
and issues a tree permit authorizing the site development.
    C.   Every tree preservation plan required by this section shall be
submitted to the Public Works Department of the village, along with an
application for a tree permit, and shall be accompanied at a minimum by the
following:
       1.   A detailed description of the proposed site development, including
a list of any and all heavy machinery that is expected to be employed and
copies of any and all engineering plans or documents; and
       2.   A copy of the village arborist's written determination; and
       3.   A list of all protective measures that will be employed to prevent
or mitigate as much as possible any negative impact upon the tree(s) identified
in the village arborist's written determination.
    Every tree preservation plan so submitted must be developed in consultation
with a licensed or certified arborist and shall bear such arborist's signature
and certification. The village reserves the right to require that additional
protective measures be added to a tree preservation plan as a condition of
approval.
    D.   Any person that engages in site development on any parcel of private
property without securing a written determination from a village arborist in
violation of this section is guilty of a business offense and shall be fined in
an amount equal to fifty dollars ($50.00). In addition, to the extent that the
site development undertaken by any person liable under this Subsection C causes
any damage to any tree located on any parcel of public property, that person
shall also be liable for such damage as set forth in Section 7-5-5 of this
chapter.
    E.   Any person that engages in site development on any parcel of private
property without receiving approval of a tree preservation plan and a tree
permit shall, if such approvals were required by this section, be guilty of a
business offense and shall be fined in an amount equal to one hundred and fifty
dollars ($150.00). In addition, to the extent that the site development
undertaken by any person liable under this Subsection D causes any damage to
any tree located on any parcel of public property, that person shall also be
liable for such damage as set forth in Section 7-5-5 of this chapter.
    F.   In the event that any person requests and receives approval of a tree
preservation plan and tree permit under this section, undertakes the approved
site development, and as a result causes any damage to any tree located on any
parcel of public property, that person shall not be guilty of any offense or
otherwise held liable for such damage unless the village proves that the person
failed to comply with any of the protective measures set out in the approved
tree preservation plan. If the village proves that the person failed to comply
with any of the protective measures set out in the tree preservation plan, the
person shall be liable for any and all damage caused, as set forth in Section
7-5-5 of this chapter. (Ord. 2019-19, 8-27-2019)
 
7-5-1012: CONSERVATION AREAS/EASEMENTS:
    A.   For the purposes of this chapter, any area or parcel of property that
is or may be dedicated to the village for the purposes of conservation and/or
preservation shall be considered "public property" for the purposes of applying
this chapter to any trees located within any such area or parcel.
    B.    To the extent that any plat, agreement, or other legally-operative
document used to affect the dedication of a conservation area or easement to
the village (i.e. the dedication document) has restrictions or provisions that
conflict with or are more restrictive than the provisions of this chapter, the
terms and provisions of the dedication document shall control. (Ord. 2019-19,
8-27-2019)
 
7-5-13: TREE PRESERVATION AND MANAGEMENT DURING CONSTRUCTION:
A.   Tree protection of public property trees for construction taking place on
or near public properties shall be handled in a manner that is fully compliant
with all applicable guidelines contained in the village's Urban Forest
Management Plan, as amended from time to time.
 
7-5-1114: TREE PERMITS:
    A.   Every applicant for a tree permit shall submit their request to the
Village Clerk on a form to be provided by the village.
    B.   Upon receipt of any application for a tree permit, the Village Clerk
shall, as soon thereafter as practicable, forward said application to the
Superintendent.
    C.    The Superintendent shall, with the assistance of the village
arborists, review the application and shall, within thirty (30) days after
receipt, make a final written determination either issuing or denying the tree
permit. However, if the Superintendent, in his or her sole discretion,
determines that additional information is needed in order to fully process the
application, he or she shall have the authority to request such additional
information from the applicant and the time for the Superintendent's final
written determination shall be extended until thirty (30) days after all
information so requested is received from the applicant.
    D.   In the event that the Superintendent refuses to issue any requested
tree permit, the applicant shall have the right to appeal said decision to the
Village Board. Any such appeal must be filed, if at all, in writing with the
Village Clerk within thirty (30) days of the Superintendent's final
determination. The decision of the Village Board on all appeals is and shall be
the final administrative decision of the village.
    E.   Every tree permit issued pursuant to this chapter shall be good for a
period of one (1) year from the date of issuance and shall expire if the work
authorized by the tree permit is not commenced within such one (1) year period.
    F.    Every tree permit issued pursuant to this chapter shall be subject to
any and all reasonable conditions and restrictions that the Superintendent (or
the Village Board, in the case of appeal) determines are necessary to ensure
compliance with all applicable guidelines contained in the village's Urban
Forest Management Plan. (Ord. 2019-19, 8-27-2019)
 
7-5-1215: CIVIL ENFORCEMENT:
    A.   The Superintendent is, with the assistance of the Village Attorney,
authorized to take any action permitted under the constitution and laws of the
State of Illinois that he deems necessary to enforce the provisions of this
chapter, including but not limited to sending cease and desist letters, issuing
stop-work orders, and filing lawsuits.
    Every violation of this chapter may be enforced, in the Superintendent's
discretion, by administrative proceedings before the village's code hearing
department or else in any manner available to the village in equity or at law.
(Ord. 2019-19, 8-27-2019)
 
   SECTION 3.   In the event that any provision or provisions, portion or
portions, or clause or clauses of this Ordinance shall be declared to be
invalid or unenforceable by a Court of competent jurisdiction, such
adjudication shall in no way affect or impair the validity or enforceability of
any of the remaining provisions, portions, or clauses of this Ordinance that
may be given effect without such invalid or unenforceable provision or
provisions, portion or portions, or clause or clauses.
 
   SECTION 4.   That all ordinances, resolutions, motions, or parts thereof,
conflicting with any of the provisions of this Ordinance, are hereby repealed
to the extent of the conflict.
 
   SECTION 5.   That the Village Clerk is hereby directed to publish this
Ordinance in pamphlet form.
 
   SECTION 6.   That this Ordinance shall be in full force and effect from and
after its passage, approval and publication in pamphlet form as provided by
law.
 
   PRESENTED and passed by the Board of Trustees on a roll call vote on the 26
th of August 2025.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
ORDINANCE NO.   2025-29
 
AN ORDINANCE AMENDING PROVISIONS OF THE MINOOKA ZONING ORDINANCE REGARDING
PERMITTED USES WITHIN THE DATA CENTER DISTRICT

   WHEREAS, the Corporate Authorities of the Village of Minooka, Will, Grundy,
and Kendall Counties, Illinois, have the authority to adopt ordinances and to
promulgate rules and regulations that pertain to its government and affairs and
protect the public health, safety, and welfare of its citizens; and
   WHEREAS, pursuant to Article 11, Division 13 of the Illinois Municipal Code
(65 ILCS 11-13-1, et seq.) the Corporate Authorities of the Village have
authority to enact zoning ordinances that regulate land use within the Village;
and
   WHEREAS, the Corporate Authorities of the Village previously exercised this
authority, enacting Title 5 (Zoning) of the Minooka Village Code (the “Minooka
Zoning Ordinance”); and
   WHEREAS, the Village previously proposed amendments to the Minooka Zoning
Ordinance to include fire stations as a permitted use within the data center
zoning district (the “Proposed Amendment”); and
   WHEREAS, the Proposed Amendment was submitted to the Planning and Zoning
Commission (the “Plan Commission”) for its review and consideration and for the
purposes of holding a public hearing thereon; and
   WHEREAS, the Plan Commission held a public hearing to consider the Proposed
Amendment on September 9, 2025, with notice having been properly given for the
same, and at that time made all findings of fact and recommendations,
incorporated by reference as “Exhibit A”, which are required by and pursuant to
the Village Code; and
   WHEREAS, the Plan Commission has recommended that the President and Board of
Trustees amend the Minooka Zoning Ordinance as set forth in this Ordinance; and
   WHEREAS, the President and Board of Trustees of the Village hereby approve
and adopt the Plan Commission’s recommendation of approval and further find and
declare that amending the Minooka Zoning Ordinance as set forth in this
Ordinance is in the best interests of the Village and its citizens.
   NOW THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED BY THE CORPORATE AUTHORITIES OF THE VILLAGE OF
MINOOKA, WILL, GRUNDY, AND KENDALL COUNTIES, ILLINOIS, PURSUANT TO ITS
STATUTORY AUTHORITY, AS FOLLOWS:
   SECTION 1.   The Corporate Authorities hereby find that all of the recitals
contained in the preamble to this Ordinance are true, correct, and complete and
are hereby incorporated by reference hereto and made a part hereof.
 
 
 
 
SECTION 2.   That Title 5 (Zoning), Chapter 17 (Data Centers), Section 5-17-3
(Data Center District) of the Minooka Village Code is hereby amended to include
the underlined text, as follows:
5-17-3: DATA CENTER DISTRICT:
A. Permitted Uses:
***
      Fire stations
***
   SECTION 3.   In the event that any provision or provisions, portion or
portions, or clause or clauses of this Ordinance shall be declared to be
invalid or unenforceable by a Court of competent jurisdiction, such
adjudication shall in no way affect or impair the validity or enforceability of
any of the remaining provisions, portions, or clauses of this Ordinance that
may be given effect without such invalid or unenforceable provision or
provisions, portion or portions, or clause or clauses.
   SECTION 4.   That all ordinances, resolutions, motions, or parts thereof,
conflicting with any of the provisions of this Ordinance, are hereby repealed
to the extent of the conflict.
   SECTION 5.   That the Village Clerk is hereby directed to publish this
Ordinance in pamphlet form.
   SECTION 6.   That this Ordinance shall be in full force and effect from and
