6-6-3: RESERVATION OF ADDITIONAL LAND FOR PUBLIC USE:
Nothing herein contained shall limit the authority of the village to require
the designation and reservation of other recreational land, school sites, or
other public lands as a condition for approval of any plat of subdivision where
such land is to be acquired by condemnation within one year from final plat
approval as set forth under division 12 of article 11 of the Illinois municipal
code1. 65 ILCS.1. (Ord. 2003-07, 2-25-2003)
6-6-4: COMBINATION WITH ADJOINING DEVELOPMENT:
Where the subdivision is less than forty (40) acres, a park or recreational
site which is to be dedicated should, where possible, be combined with
dedications from adjoining subdivisions in order to produce usable park or
recreational sites without hardship on a particular subdivider. (Ord. 2003-07,
2-25-2003)
6-6-5: TOPOGRAPHY AND GRADING:
The slope, topography and geology of the dedicated site as well as its
surroundings must be suitable for its intended purposes. Grading on sites
dedicated for park and recreational uses shall not differ greatly from
surrounding land. (Ord. 2003-07, 2-25-2003)
6-6-6: IMPROVED SITES:
All sites shall be dedicated in a condition ready for full service of
electrical, water, sewer and streets (including enclosed drainage and curb and
gutter) as applicable to the location of the site, or acceptable provisions
made therefor, and all other improvements shall be made as may be required by
the subdivision code. (Ord. 2003-07, 2-25-2003)
6-6-7: PREREQUISITE TO ANNEXATION AGREEMENT:
The dedications of land or cash contributions in lieu thereof or combination of
both as required by this chapter shall also be a matter of policy of the
village and provisions therefor shall be incorporated in any annexation
agreement governing such land. (Ord. 2003-07, 2-25-2003)
6-6-8: TIME OF DEDICATION OR PAYMENT:
The dedication of land shall be made at the time of final plat approval by the
board of trustees for the proposed subdivision. Cash contributions shall be
made at the time of the issuance of the building permits for the subject
residential dwelling units. (Ord. 2003-07, 2-25-2003)
6-6-9: METHOD OF PAYMENT:
The cash contributions required hereunder shall be made by check payable to the
village and shall be deposited with the village clerk prior to the issuance of
a building permit. (Ord. 2003-07, 2-25-2003)
CHAPTER 7
PLANNED UNIT DEVELOPMENTS
SECTION:
6-7-1 Purpose
6-7-2 Objectives
6-7-3 Permitted Uses In A PUD
6-7-4 Qualifications For Filing
6-7-5 Procedure
6-7-6 Requirements For Submission
6-7-7 Changes
6-7-8 Design Incentives
6-7-9 Design Requirements
6-7-10 Review Criteria
6-7-1: PURPOSE:
The provisions of this Chapter are intended for special situations in which:
   A.   Special amenities and benefits to the Village beyond those required by
this and other Village ordinances can be achieved by allowing more flexible
design than is otherwise permitted by such requirements; or
   B.   Properties with unique constraints such as environmentally sensitive
areas or infill parcels require a more flexible approach to land use control to
make possible development that is sensitive to such constraints. (Ord. 1997-08,
5-27-1997)
6-7-2: OBJECTIVES:
   A.   To promote flexibility in design and permit planned diversification in
the location of structures.
   B.   To promote an efficient use of land to facilitate sustainability in the
arrangement of buildings, circulation systems, utilities, open space and
natural resources.
   C.   To preserve existing natural resources and landscape features and to
utilize them in a manner harmonious with the development.
   D.   To provide for more usable and suitably located recreation facilities
and other public facilities than would otherwise be provided under conventional
development.
   E.   To provide for the aesthetic and functional harmony of various types of
buildings, land uses, and landscape elements. (Ord. 1997-08, 5-27-1997)
6-7-3: PERMITTED USES IN A PUD:
   A.   Residential PUDs are permitted under the provisions of this Chapter in
the R Districts and may include any uses permitted by right, conditional uses,
or accessory uses in the underlying R District. A maximum of ten percent (10%)
of the gross site in an R District may be devoted to commercial uses provided
these uses are permitted by right in the B1 District or as conditional
permitted uses in the B1 District.
   B.   Commercial PUDs are permitted under the provisions of this Chapter in
the B Districts and may include any uses permitted by right, conditional
permitted uses, or accessory uses as provided in the underlying B District.
   C.   Industrial PUDs are permitted under the provisions of this Chapter in
the I Districts and may include any uses permitted by right, conditional
permitted uses, or accessory uses as provided in the underlying I District.
   D.   Mixed use PUDs are permitted under the provisions of this Chapter,
provided that the underlying district boundaries conform with the uses being
proposed except that ten percent (10%) of the gross site area of an R zoned
portion of the PUD may be devoted to uses permitted in the B1 District.
   E.   Data Center PUDS are permitted under the provisions of this chapter in
the data center district and may include any uses permitted by right,
conditional permitted uses, or accessory uses as provided in the underlying
data center district.
   F.   The uses included in any proposed PUD are subject to the review and
approval procedures specified herein and shall not be deemed to be permitted by
right. (Ord. 1997-08, 5-27-1997; amd. Ord. 2025-3, 4-22-2025)
6-7-4: QUALIFICATIONS FOR FILING:
No development shall be filed as a planned unit development unless it:
   A.   Is at least one acre in size, and
   B.   Is initially under the same ownership or control. (Ord. 1997-08, 5-27-
1997)
6-7-5: PROCEDURE:
A planned unit development shall be granted as a conditional permitted use to
the zoning district(s) in which it is located. The process for a planned unit
development shall be as follows:
   A.   Pre-Application:
      1.   Prior to filing a formal application, the applicant thereof should
meet with the appropriate Village staff to discuss the proposed development.
The applicant should be able to provide a concept of the PUD at this time.
Staff will advise the applicant at this time of all applicable officially
adopted policies, standards, regulations and procedures.
      2.   A concept review before the Village Planning and Zoning Commission
may be directed at the discretion of Village staff or upon the request of the
applicant. A concept review provides the Commission an opportunity to determine
what additional information will be necessary concerning the application.
   B.   Preliminary Plat Of Planned Unit Development: Procedure for the
submission of the preliminary plat for a planned unit development shall be
identical to the preliminary plat procedure described in Section
6-2-1 of this Title except that it shall be accompanied by an application for a
conditional permitted use for a planned unit development in accordance with the
procedures for conditional permitted uses established in Section
5-11-9 of this Code.
   C.   Conditional Permitted Use For Planned Unit Development: Concurrent with
the application for preliminary plat for a planned unit development, the
applicant shall submit an application for a conditional permitted use for a
planned unit development. The conditional use permit shall be approved
contingent upon final PUD approval.
   D.   Final Plat Of Planned Unit Development: Procedure for submission of the
final plat of planned unit development shall be identical to the final plat
procedure described in Section
6-2-1 of this Title. (Ord. 1997-08, 5-27-1997)
6-7-6: REQUIREMENTS FOR SUBMISSION:
   A.   Pre-Application: The following items need to be provided by the
applicant for a pre- application conference review to occur:
      1.   General Site Information: Data regarding site conditions, land
characteristics, available community facilities and utilities, and other
related information.
      2.   Concept Plan: A drawing in simple sketch form showing the proposed
location, land uses, streets, buildings, and other related information.
   B.   Preliminary Plat Of Planned Unit Development:
      1.   Required Information: In addition to the requirements for
preliminary plat set forth in Section 6-2-2 of this Title, the following items
and information are required for the submission of a planned unit development:
         a.   Statement Of Objectives: A statement of the objectives to be
achieved by the PUD. This statement should provide the rationale behind the
assumptions and choices of the developer/applicant. This statement should
explain the benefits to the Village that will result from the PUD.
         b.   Statement Of Character: Explanation of the character of the PUD
and the manner in which it has been planned to take advantage of the
flexibility of these regulations.
         c.   List Of Variances: A list of the variances from the zoning and
subdivision ordinances that are being employed in the proposed PUD.
         d.   Design Schedule: A list of the area, lot width, yard, setback and
bulk requirements applicable to the PUD.
         e.   Preliminary Landscape Plan: A landscape plan showing all
landscape improvements (both plantings and hardscape) being proposed in the
PUD. Details should be provided for landscape design elements intended for
screening or buffering as well as for any unique landscape design features such
as entry features, parks, etc.
      2.   Optional Additional Information: In addition, the Planning and
Zoning Commission or Village Board may request at any time during the review
process that the applicant provide any of the following additional items:
         a.   Architectural Plans: If directed by the Planning and Zoning
Commission, the applicant shall submit preliminary architectural plans for all
primary buildings that shall be submitted in sufficient detail to allow an
understanding of the style of the development except for single-family detached
structures proposed to be constructed on lots in compliance with all applicable
zoning district requirements.
         b.   School Impact Analysis: Provide information on the student count
to be generated by the PUD and the financial impact on the local school
districts.
         c.   Tax Impact Analysis: Provide information on the taxes to be
generated by the proposed project and the cost for the various taxing bodies to
provide the necessary services.
         d.   Traffic Analysis: Provide information on the traffic to be
generated by the PUD and the adequacy of the local transportation and
thoroughfare to handle the anticipated volumes. Also an analysis may be
necessary of the internal streets, drives, parking, sidewalks and pathways.
         e.   Covenants And Restrictions: Provide any proposed covenants and
restrictions, agreements or provisions that will govern the use, maintenance,
and continued protection of the PUD.
   C.   Final Plat Of Planned Unit Development: In addition to the requirements
for final plat set forth in Section 6-2-4 of this Title, the following items
and information are required for the submission of a final plat of planned unit
development:
      1.   Landscaping Plans: Final landscape plans and landscape details.
      2.   Covenants And Restrictions: Provide the final covenants and
restrictions, agreements or provisions that will govern the use, maintenance,
and continued protection of the PUD. (Ord. 1997-08, 5-27-1997)
6-7-7: CHANGES:
A planned unit development shall be constructed in complete accordance with the
approved preliminary and final plat of planned unit development and all
supporting data. Major changes to an approved preliminary or final plat of
planned unit development require the resubmission and reconsideration of the
planned unit development according to the process set forth herein for
preliminary and final plat approval. With the aid of the following criteria,
the Zoning Officer shall be responsible for determining whether a change is
classified as major or minor. Minor changes shall, at the direction of the
Zoning Officer, be brought before the Planning and Zoning Commission for final
action but shall not require a new public hearing.
   A.   Criteria For Major Change: A major change is one that alters the
concept or intent of the planned unit development. This includes, but is not
limited to:
      1.   For A Residential PUD:
         a.   Any change in the location, size or type of dwelling units or
land uses.
         b.   Any increase in the number of dwelling units from that in the
approved preliminary plat.
         c.   Any change, greater than ten percent (10%), in the height of any
building or structure in the PUD other than single-family detached dwelling
units.
         d.   Any change in the functional classification of a roadway.
         e.   Any reduction in the acreage of open space.
      2.   For A Nonresidential PUD Or Nonresidential Portion Of A PUD:
         a.   Any change in the location or type of land use.
         b.   Any change in the type, number or location of a building.
         c.   Greater than a ten percent (10%) increase in the height of a
building.
         d.   Any change in the functional classification of a roadway.
         e.   Any reduction in the acreage of open space.
         f.   A greater than ten percent (10%) increase in the gross floor area
of a nonresidential building.
         g.   A greater than ten percent (10%) increase in the total gross
floor area of all the nonresidential buildings in the PUD.
         h.   Any reduction in the total number of parking spaces for the
project.
   B.   Criteria For Minor Change: Minor changes are changes not defined as
major changes and which do not alter the concept or intent of a PUD. (Ord.
1997-08, 5-27-1997)
6-7-8: DESIGN INCENTIVES:
To further creativity and excellence in design, the following incentives are
offered in planned unit developments:
   A.   Varied Zoning Requirements: Bulk requirements of the underlying zoning
district(s) may be varied provided that it can be demonstrated that the
variations conform to all of the review criteria contained herein as well as
those established for conditional uses and those established for subdivision
plats.
   B.   Varied Subdivision Requirements: Dimensional and design standards for
subdivisions and subdivision improvements such as streets, blocks, sidewalks,
and parkways may vary from Village and IDOT standards established or referenced
in the Village subdivision regulations provided that it can be demonstrated
that the variations conform to all of the review criteria contained herein as
well as those established for conditional permitted uses and those established
for subdivision plats. Required subdivision improvements may not vary from the
required construction improvement specifications.
   C.   Mixed Uses: A PUD may include a variety of land uses designed and
planned as part of a unified development provided that the underlying zoning
conforms to the uses being proposed. A residential PUD in an R District may
include up to ten percent (10%) of the gross site area devoted to uses
permitted in the B1 Zoning District.
   D.   On-Site Density Transfer: The density permitted in a given portion of a
total site may be transferred to another portion of the site in order to
preserve environmentally sensitive areas and to achieve excellence in design
provided that the gross density does not exceed the maximum allowed herein for
the underlying zoning district.
   E.   Density Bonuses: Design excellence in the provision of site amenities
such as exceptional landscaping, recreational facilities, preservation of
architectural and historic sites, and the preservation of environmentally
sensitive areas may allow the granting of an increase in density of up to five
percent (5%).
Flexibility to suspend requirements imposed by the Village's zoning and
subdivision regulations is not conferred upon the PUD applicant as a matter of
right, but in all cases subject to the finding by the Village that the
objectives of these provisions are being served by the PUD and that all
applicable review standards are being adhered to. Variations in a PUD from
normally applicable standards shall not be considered as variances as defined
in this Title and shall not be required to conform to the approval criteria
herein provided for variances. (Ord. 1997-08, 5-27-1997)
6-7-9: DESIGN REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Maximum Density:
      1.   Residential PUD: The gross maximum density of a residential PUD
shall not exceed the following standard for the district in which it is
situated:
 
R1  1 du/acre
R1A 3 du/acre
R2  4 du/acre
    4 du/acre for single-family detached dwellings
R3  6 du/acre for single-family attached
    12 du/acre for multi-family
R4  6 du/acre
R5  6 du/acre
R6  12 du/acre
 
      2.   Nonresidential PUD: As required in the underlying zoning district.
   B.   Spacing:
      1.   The minimum distance between single-family detached dwellings shall
be ten feet (10').
      2.   The minimum distance between buildings other than single-family
detached dwellings less than twenty four feet (24') in height shall be fifteen
feet (15').
      3.   The minimum distance between buildings greater than twenty four feet
(24') in height shall be equal to the height of the taller building.
   C.   Yards: The required yards along the periphery of the PUD shall be at
least equal to that of the underlying zoning district. (Ord. 1997-08, 5-27-
1997)
6-7-10: REVIEW CRITERIA:
The Planning and Zoning Commission's review of the preliminary and final PUD
applications shall be based on the following criteria:
   A.   The PUD shall not in any way be deemed to be detrimental to the public
health, safety, comfort or general welfare.
   B.   The plan of the area proposed for the PUD shall be in general
conformance with the adopted Comprehensive Plan of the Village.
   C.   The use or uses within the PUD shall be compatible with surrounding
land uses and will not be injurious to the use and enjoyment of other
properties in its vicinity.
   D.   Ingress and egress to the PUD shall be provided in a manner to
facilitate access by emergency vehicles and efficient and safe traffic
circulation in the vicinity and be consistent with any officially adopted plans
of the Village. Sidewalks, pedestrianways, bicycle paths and off-street parking
and loading are provided in a location and capacity appropriate to the planned
uses.
   E.   The quality or quantity of common open spaces and landscaping provided
are consistent with the higher standards of amenity and design required of a
PUD.
   F.   Adequate provision has been made in the form of deed restrictions,
homeowners' or condominium associations, or the like for the preservation and
maintenance of any open spaces, private roads or drives, utilities, and storm
water management facilities as well as for the control of architectural review
for individual structures if necessary to implement the PUD.
   G.   Adequate and safe location of play areas for children as well as other
recreational areas.
   H.   Buildings shall be located so as to ensure adequate light and air.
   I.   The PUD shall be of a superior design than would otherwise be permitted
by the strict adherence to otherwise applicable regulations and exceeding that
which is typical of conventional development.
   J.   The PUD meets the minimum requirements set forth in this Chapter as
well as the provisions of all other sections of this Ordinance as well as the
Village's Subdivision Ordinance, unless specifically excluded by this Chapter
or waived by the Village Board.
   K.   All construction shall conform to the requirements of the Village.
(Ord. 1997-08, 5-27-1997)
TITLE 7
HEALTH AND SANITATION
CHAPTER 1
NUISANCES
SECTION:
7-1-1 Nuisances Enumerated
7-1-2 Penalty, Notice To Abate
7-1-3 Abatement By Village
7-1-4 Burning Of Waste Materials
7-1-1: NUISANCE ENUMERATED:
Within the territorial jurisdiction of the Village, it is hereby declared to be
a nuisance for any person:
   A.   To so negligently conduct any business or use any premises as to create
an offensive smell as may taint the air and render it unwholesome and
disagreeable to other persons.
   B.   To cause or to suffer the carcass of any animal or other offal, filth
or noisome substance to be collected, deposited or remain in any place to the
prejudice of other persons.
   C.   To throw or deposit any offal or otherwise offensive matter or the
carcass of any animal in any watercourse, pond, spring or well.
   D.   To deposit any night soil, dead animal or other filthy, offensive or
noisome substance upon any lot, street, alley, highway, park or other place.
   E.   To obstruct or impede, without legal authority, the passage of any
gutter or natural drainage of any public or private property.
   F.   To obstruct or encroach upon public highways, private ways, streets,
alleys or commons.
   G.   To establish, maintain or carry on any offensive or unwholesome
business within the limits of the Village, or within one mile of the limits
thereof.
   H.   To throw or deposit any straw, dirt, filth, chips, ashes or other
rubbish in any alley or other public place.
   I.   To permit or suffer any offal, filth, refuse, animal or vegetable
matter, which is liable to become putrid or offensive or injurious to health,
to remain on any premises used or occupied by him for a longer period than four
(4) hours at any one time.
   J.   To keep or suffer to keep, in a foul, offensive, nauseous or filthy
condition any railroad car, building, yard, cellar, barn, sewer, pig sty or
privy.
   K.   To own, keep or use any railroad car, yard, pen, place or premises in
or upon which cattle or swine may be confined or kept, as to be offensive to
persons residing in the vicinity of the same.
   L.   To erect, continue or use any building or other place for the exercise
of any trade, employment or manufacture which, by occasioning noxious
exhalations, offensive smells or otherwise is offensive or dangerous to the
health of individuals or the public.
   M.   To locate and use, without first having obtained permission of the
Village President and Board of Trustees, to do so, any packing house, rendery,
tallow chandlery, bone factory, tannery, brewery, distillery, livery stable,
blacksmith shop or foundry.
   N.   To erect or use habitually any house or lot for the purpose of
butchering or slaughtering cattle, calves, sheep or swine without the
permission of the President and Board of Trustees.
   O.   To boil or render tainted lard or other animal substance so as to taint
the air, render it unwholesome or offensive.
   P.   To use in the erection of, or repairing of any building a scaffold or
scaffolds not wide enough to ensure the safety of the persons passing under or
near the same.
   Q.   To suffer any bitch or slut, owned by him to run at large while in
heat.
   R.   To suffer any horse, ox, cow, calf, hog, dog, cat or other animal owned
by him or in his charge which may come to its death in any manner, to lie for
more than twenty four (24) hours after its death, in or upon any street, alley
or other ground, public or private.
   S.   To erect or continue any public sign indicating that any premises or
building owned, occupied or in charge of such person is used in whole or in
part as a saloon or dramshop, unless such person shall have a license to keep a
dramshop, issued by the village president and the board of trustees. (1904 Code
§ 17.1; amd. 1997 Code)
   T.   To leave any vehicles parked on a village street during street cleaning
or snow removal operations. (Ord. 1978-5, 1978)
   U.   To demolish any structure by fire. (Ord. 1987-5, 2-25-1987)
   V.   In an eviction by a landlord of a tenant, it shall be a nuisance: (Ord.
1988-15, 10-10-1988)
      1.   For a landlord to cause tenant's goods and chattels to be removed
from the landlord's premises and deposited upon any street, alley, avenue or
other public ground within the village, unless such goods and chattels shall be
enclosed within a good and sufficient container as provided in section
7-2-4 of this title. Twenty four (24) hours shall be considered a reasonable
time to remove or abate such nuisance.
      2.   For the owner of goods and chattels which a landlord has caused to
be removed from the landlord's premises and deposited upon any street, alley,
avenue or other public ground within the village, to allow such goods and
chattels to remain upon the public grounds. If such goods and chattels are not
enclosed in a container as provided in section
7-2-4 of this title, then twenty four (24) hours shall be considered a
reasonable time to remove or abate such nuisance. If such goods and chattels
are enclosed within a container as provided in section
7-2-4 of this title, then seven (7) days shall be considered a reasonable time
to remove or abate such nuisance. (Ord. 1988-15, 10-10-1988; amd. Ord. 2014-32,
12-16-2014)
   W.   To pull up or break down or otherwise injure any of the trees, grass,
shrubbery, fences, seats, stands or other fixtures or things in or about, or
appertaining to any public square or park in the village; or to erect any booth
or other structure on any such public square or park without the written
permission of the president of the village first being obtained by such person.
(1904 Code § 26.11)
7-1-2: PENALTY, NOTICE TO ABATE:
Any person who shall violate any provision of this chapter shall be punishable
as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code.
Provided, that the offender shall, in every case under this chapter, be
notified by some officer of the village to remove or abate such nuisance, and
be allowed a reasonable time, to be fixed by such officer in such notice
according to the nature of the nuisance, to so remove and abate the same, and
upon so doing within the time fixed by such officer, the offender shall not be
subject to the penalty aforesaid, unless the commission of such nuisance was
wilful or resulted in the actual damage to the person or property affected.
(1904 Code § 17.2; amd. 1977 Code)
7-1-3: ABATEMENT BY VILLAGE:
If any person guilty of creating, suffering or continuing any nuisance defined
in this chapter shall, upon being notified as aforesaid, neglect or refuse to
remove, abate or discontinue such nuisance within the time specified in such
notice, it shall be the duty of the village police to cause such nuisance to be
abated or removed, and he shall keep an accurate account of the necessary
expense incurred thereby, which expense shall be collected from the offender by
an action of debt in the name of the village, before the proper village
officer, and the removal or abatement of such nuisance by the village police
and the collection of the expenses thereby incurred, as herein provided, shall
be no bar to the prosecution for the recovery of the penalty provided in
section
7-1-2 of this chapter. (1904 Code § 17.3)
7-1-4: BURNING OF WASTE MATERIALS:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to burn waste materials within the
village limits, except as regulated herein. Any person violating this section
shall be punishable as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code.
   B.   All burning of waste materials is subject to the following regulations:
      1.   Burning Prohibited: Except as hereinafter provided it shall be
unlawful to burn any material, including, but not limited to, "landscape waste"
and "municipal waste" as hereinafter defined.
      2.   Definitions:
   LANDSCAPE WASTE: All accumulations of grass or shrubbery, leaves and all
other materials accumulated in the care of lawns, shrubbery and vines.
   MUNICIPAL WASTE: Garbage, general household and commercial waste, industrial
lunchroom or office waste, landscape waste and construction or demolition
debris.
      3.   Exceptions: The following open burning activities are permitted
within the village:
         a.   The setting of fires by the forest preserve district of any
county on property owned or controlled by it, to perform prescribed burning for
natural community and habitat management;
         b.   The setting of fires to combat or limit existing fires, when
reasonable and necessary in the judgment of the responsible government
official;
         c.   The burning of fuels for legitimate campfire, recreational, and
cooking purposes, or in domestic fireplaces, in areas which such burning is
consistent with other laws, provided that no garbage shall be burned in such
cases;
         d.   Small open flames for heating tar or for welding, acetylene
torches, highway safety flares, and the like.
   C.   Fires shall be located not less than fifty feet (50') from any
structure, with adequate provisions made to prevent the spread of fire, or the
fire shall be contained in a fireproof container located not less than fifteen
feet (15') from any structure.
   D.   All fires shall be constantly attended until such fire is extinguished.
The person attending the fire shall be equipped with a hose connected to a
water supply, or other fire extinguishing equipment, suitable to extinguish the
fire.
   E.   Prior to starting the fire, the appropriate fire protection district
shall be notified of the location of the fire, the nature of the materials to
be burned, the date and time of the fire, and the name of the person to be
attending the fire.
   F.   No waste materials may be burned on any village or public street or
alley.
   G.   It shall be unlawful to burn styrofoam, polystyrene, any other kind of
plastic material, shingles, or insulation. It shall be unlawful to burn any
materials in which the above materials may be incorporated.
   H.   The owner of the property where the fire is to be located, the person
owning the materials to be burned, the person responsible for causing the
materials to be burned, and the person attending the fire are each jointly
responsible to see that the regulations set forth in this section are not
violated. (Ord. 2003-02, 1-28-2003)
CHAPTER 2
GARBAGE AND REFUSE
SECTION:
7-2-1 System Of Collection
7-2-2 Contract For Collection; Letting Of Bids
7-2-3 Collection Of Garbage, Requirements
7-2-4 Deposits Of Garbage
7-2-5 Collection Of Garbage, Charges
7-2-6 Penalty
7-2-7 Voluntary Recycling Program
7-2-1: SYSTEM OF COLLECTION:
The village shall provide a system of collection and disposal of garbage for
the benefit of inhabitants of the village. (Ord. 1933-3, 5-1-1933; amd. 1977
Code)
7-2-2: CONTRACT FOR COLLECTION; LETTING OF BIDS:
   A.   The board of trustees of the village shall let a contract for the
collection and disposal of garbage.
   B.   The finance committee of the village board may, prior to termination of
the current contract term, procure written quotations from various contractors
for the contract of collecting and disposing of garbage, and submit their
recommendations to the board of trustees prior to the termination of the
current contract term. The village may also advertise for bidders for the
contract for the collection and disposal of garbage. (Ord. 2014-32, 12-16-2014)
7-2-3: COLLECTION OF GARBAGE, REQUIREMENTS:
The successful bidder for the contract of collecting and disposing of garbage
as aforesaid, shall collect all garbage on all premises within the village
limits at least once each week and shall transport the same through the streets
and alleys of the village in such a manner that no leakage shall occur from the
vehicle in which said garbage is transported. Said garbage, after being placed
in said vehicle, shall remain covered while the same is being transported on
any street or alley within the village limits.
The successful bidder for the contract herein provided for shall remove said
garbage to a place outside the village limits. (Ord., 1985)
7-2-4: DEPOSITS OF GARBAGE:
   A.   No garbage of any description shall be deposited upon any street,
alley, vacant lot, public grounds or private premises within the village
limits, except by direction or written permission of the board of health of the
village. It shall be the duty of the occupant of every home, hotel, tavern,
eating house and other premises to, at all times, have the garbage upon his
premises collected and deposited in suitable containers. Such containers shall
be located so as to be convenient of access to the garbage collector.
   B.   All persons are hereby prohibited from placing any substance other than
garbage within the containers herein provided for, and shall be further
required to keep ashes separate from cans and other refuse.
   C.   Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be punishable
as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 2014-32, 12-16-2014)
7-2-5: COLLECTION OF GARBAGE, CHARGES:
   A.   There are hereby established charges for the collection of garbage and
refuse from each family residential unit in the village.
   B.   The charge shall be:
 
                          Effective Date - July 1 Cost
64 or 96 gallon container 2020                    23.75
                         2021                    24.46
                         2022                    25.19
                         2023                    25.95
                         2024                    26.76
 
   C.   The charges shall be billed bimonthly along with the water and sewer
service billings.
   D.   Provided that sufficient proof is given to the Village annually to
establish that at least one head of household of a residential unit in the
Village is age sixty five (65) or older, the charge for collection of garbage
and refuse shall be reduced by two dollars ($2.00) per month for the
residential unit. (Ord. 2014-32, 12-16-2014; amd. Ord. 2017-29, 11-21-2017;
Ord. 2020-21, 7-28-2020)
7-2-6: PENALTY:
The penalty prescribed for violation of any of the provisions of this chapter
shall be as set out under section
1-4-1 of this Code. (Ord. 1981-17, 11-23-1981)
7-2-7: VOLUNTARY RECYCLING PROGRAM:
   A.   Recyclables are materials having an economic value in the secondary
materials market. The following materials have such economic value: aluminum
cans and articles, bimetal cans, glass containers, corrugated paper (cardboard
and paper boxes), magazines, computer printout paper, computer tax cards,
office paper, steel cans, newspaper, paper products not chemically coated.
   B.   There is hereby established a Recycling Program for the voluntary
separating of recyclables from garbage and rubbish in the Village of Minooka.
   C.   Recyclables shall be prepared and separated from other refuse as
required and shall be collected by the Village, or by its designated agent.
Recyclables shall be placed either at the curbside to be collected at times
designated by the Village or shall be taken to a recycling facility.
   D.   Recyclable items shall become the property of the Village from time of
placement of the recyclables at the curb or in the recycling shelters. It shall
be a violation of this section for any person not authorized by the Village to
collect or pick up or cause to be collected or picked up any such items. Any
and each such collection in violation hereof from one or more locations shall
constitute a separate and distinct offense punishable as hereinafter provided.
   It shall be unlawful for a person not authorized by the Village to collect,
remove or dispose of solid waste which contains recyclables combined with other
forms of solid waste.
   E.   Any person who violates any provision of this section shall, upon
conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine as set out in section
1-4-1 of this Code.
   F.   Any person may donate or sell recyclables to any other person whether
operating for profit or not for profit. (Ord. 1990-10, 6-12-1990; amd. 1997
Code)
CHAPTER 3
NOXIOUS WEEDS
SECTION:
7-3-1: Nuisance Declared
7-3-2: Height Limit
7-3-3: Notice To Abate
7-3-4: Charges To Abate
7-3-5: Charges, Lien
7-3-6: Penalty
7-3-1: NUISANCE DECLARED:
Any weeds such as jimson, burdock, ragweed, thistle, cocklebur, poison ivy,
poison oak, poison sumac or other weeds of a like kind, found growing in any
lot or tract of land in the village except in residentially zoned, unsubdivided
land are hereby declared to be a nuisance, and it shall be unlawful to permit
any such weeds to grow or remain in such places. (1997 Code)
7-3-2: HEIGHT LIMIT:
It shall be unlawful for anyone to permit any weeds, grass or plants, other
than trees, bushes, flowers or other ornamental plants to grow to a height
exceeding one foot (1') anywhere in the village, and such plants or weeds
exceeding such heights are hereby declared to be a nuisance. (1977 Code; amd.
1997 Code)
7-3-3: NOTICE TO ABATE:
It shall be the duty of the village clerk to serve or cause to be served a
notice upon the owner or occupant of any such premises on which weeds or plants
are permitted to grow in violation of the provisions of this chapter, and to
demand the abatement of the nuisance within ten (10) days from when the notice
is mailed, hand delivered, or posted on the property. (Ord. 2011-09, 3-22-2011)
7-3-4: CHARGES TO ABATE:
If the person so notified does not abate the nuisance within ten (10) days
after such notice, the village clerk shall proceed to abate such nuisance by
having the weeds cut. The charge for cutting weeds shall be the total costs
incurred by the village in cutting and removing the weeds. A bill for the weed
cutting charges shall be served, or caused to be served, by the village clerk
upon, and shall be paid by, the owner or occupant upon receipt. (Ord. 2016-23,
7-26-2016)
7-3-5: CHARGES, LIEN:
Charges for weed cutting shall be a lien upon the premises as provided by
statute. Whenever a bill for weed cutting remains unpaid for thirty (30) days
after it has been rendered, the village clerk may file with the county recorder
of deeds, of the county having jurisdiction, a notice consisting of a sworn
statement setting out: (Ord. 1989-15, 10-24-1989; amd. 1997 Code)
   A.   A description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof,
   B.   The amount of money representing the cost and expense incurred or
payable for the service, and
   C.   The date or dates when such cost and expense were incurred by the city.
(1977 Code)
7-3-6: PENALTY:
The penalty prescribed for violation of any of the provisions of this chapter
shall be as set out under section
1-4-1 of this code. (1977 Code)
CHAPTER 4
REMOVAL AND TRIMMING OF NUISANCE TREES
SECTION:
7-4-1: Dangerous, Unsafe, Diseased, And Infested Trees On Public Property Or
Right Of Way
7-4-2: Trees On Private Property Causing Dangerous Or Unsafe Condition Other
Than A Sight Restriction
7-4-1: DANGEROUS, UNSAFE, DISEASED, AND INFESTED TREES ON PUBLIC PROPERTY OR
RIGHT OF WAY:
   A.   Where a tree is located on property owned by the village or in the
dedicated public right of way, and causes a dangerous or unsafe condition to
exist, the removal and trimming of said tree shall be in accordance with (i)
all applicable guidelines contained in the village's Urban Forest Management
Plan, as amended from time to time, (ii) with any and all applicable Illinois
laws and regulations, and (iii) with any local franchise or other agreements
with the village.
   B.   Where a tree is located on property owned by the village or in the
dedicated public right of way and said tree is determined by a certified
village arborist to be diseased or infested, care for and/or removal of such
tree(s) shall be in accordance with all applicable guidelines contained in the
village's Urban Forest Management Plan. (Ord. 2013-11, 4-23-2013; Ord. 2019-19,
8-27-2019)
7-4-2: TREES ON PRIVATE PROPERTY CAUSING DANGEROUS OR UNSAFE CONDITION OTHER
THAN A SIGHT RESTRICTION:
   A.   Where any tree located on private property causes a dangerous or unsafe
condition to exist on village-owned property, in the public right of way, or in
a dedicated village easement, the owner of the private property on which the
tree is located shall be responsible for removing or trimming said tree so as
to abate said condition. Notice and abatement shall be in accordance with the
following:
      1.   Notice: The department of public works shall give to the owner of
the premises on which the tree is located a written notice of the existence of
the condition caused by said tree. Service of the notice required by this
section shall be by personal service or by registered mail, to the person who
is listed as the taxpayer of record for said property. Said notice shall
include the following:
         a.   The common address for the property in question;
         b.   The permanent tax index number for the property in question;
         c.   A brief description of the condition;
         d.   An identification of the specific tree or trees causing the
condition; and
         e.   A statement indicating that if the identified condition is not
remedied within ten (10) days of the date of the notice, the village may
provide for abatement of the condition and bill the property owner and/or lien
the property for the    reasonable cost of said abatement.
      2.   Abatement: Upon receiving notice pursuant to this section, the
property owner must abate the dangerous or unsafe condition in a manner
consistent with all applicable guidelines in the village's Urban Forest
Management Plan. If the property owner refuses or neglects to remedy the
condition within the time frame set out in the notice, the village may provide
for abatement of the condition by removing and/or trimming said tree(s). The
reasonable cost for said removal and/or trimming shall be billed to the
property owner.
      3.   Lien: If said property owner refuses or neglects to pay said bill
within ninety (90) days, a lien in the amount of said costs shall be recorded/
registered with the county recorder of deeds/registrar of titles. Said lien
shall be recorded/registered within one (1) year after such costs are incurred
by the village, and shall consist of a sworn statement setting forth the
following:
         a.   The legal description of the property;
         b.   The permanent tax index number of the property;
         c.   The common address of the property;
         d.   The cost incurred in removing and/or trimming the tree(s); and
         e.   The date(s) on which the tree removal and/or trimming work was
performed.
      4.   Notice Of Lien: Upon the recording/registering of said lien, a copy
thereof shall be forwarded by first class U.S. mail to the taxpayer of record
for said property.
      5.   Emergency Removal And/Or Trimming: In cases where it reasonably
appears that the condition of the tree poses an imminent hazard, and there is
immediate danger to the life or safety of any property or person unless the
tree in question is immediately trimmed and/or removed, the Superintendent of
public works, or his/her duly authorized designee, shall provide for the
immediate trimming and/or removal of such dangerous tree. The costs of such
emergency trimming and/or removal shall be collected in the same manner as
provided in this section.
      6.   Lien Satisfaction: Upon receipt of payment consisting of the amount
of the lien and the village's actual cost for recording the lien, the village
shall issue a release of lien to the person making said payment.
   B.   Where any tree located on private property is determined by a certified
village arborist to be diseased or infested and the village arborist further
determines that there is a risk that said disease or infestation could spread
to other trees within the village, the owner of the private property on which
the tree is located shall be responsible for removing or trimming said tree so
as to abate said condition. Notice and abatement shall be in accordance with
the following:
      1.   Notice: The department of public works shall give to the owner of
the premises on which the tree is located a written notice of the existence of
the diseased or infested tree. Service of the notice required by this section
shall be by personal service or by registered mail, to the person who is listed
as the taxpayer of record for said property. Said notice shall include the
following:
         a.   The common address for the property in question;
         b.   The permanent tax index number for the property in question;
         c.   A brief description of the disease/infestation affecting the tree
(s) in question;
         d.   An identification of the specific tree or trees that are
diseased/infested; and
         e.   A statement indicating that if the identified condition is not
remedied within ten (10) days of the date of the notice, the village may
provide for abatement of the condition and bill the property owner and/or lien
the property for the reasonable cost of said abatement.
      2.   Abatement: Upon receiving notice pursuant to this section, the
property owner must treat or remove the diseased or infested tree(s) in a
manner consistent with all applicable guidelines in the village's Urban Forest
Management Plan. If the property owner refuses or neglects to remedy the
condition within the time frame set out in the notice, the village may provide
for abatement of the condition by treating or removing said tree(s). The
reasonable cost for said treatment and/or removal shall be billed to the
property owner.
      3.   Lien: If said property owner refuses or neglects to pay said bill
within ninety (90) days, a lien in the amount of said costs shall be recorded/
registered with the county recorder of deeds/registrar of titles. Said lien
shall be recorded/registered within one (1) year after such costs are incurred
by the village, and shall consist of a sworn statement setting forth the
following:
         a.   The legal description of the property;
         b.   The permanent tax index number of the property;
         c.   The common address of the property;
         d.   The cost incurred in removing and/or trimming the tree(s); and
         e.   The date(s) on which the tree removal and/or trimming work was
performed.
      4.   Notice Of Lien: Upon the recording/registering of said lien, a copy
thereof shall be forwarded by first class U.S. mail to the taxpayer of record
for said property.
      5.   Emergency Removal And/Or Trimming: In cases where it reasonably
appears that the condition of the diseased/infested tree poses an imminent
hazard, and there is immediate danger to the life or safety of any property or
person unless the tree in question is immediately treated and/or removed, the
Superintendent of public works, or his/her duly authorized designee, shall
provide for the immediate treatment and/or removal of such diseased or infested
tree. The costs of such emergency treatment and/or removal shall be collected
in the same manner as provided in this section.
      6.   Lien Satisfaction: Upon receipt of payment consisting of the amount
of the lien and the village's actual cost for recording the lien, the village
shall issue a release of lien to the person making said payment.
   C.   Definition Of Private Property: For purposes of this section, "private
property" shall be defined to include all property within the village which is
neither owned by the village nor is dedicated right of way. (Ord. 2013-11, 4-
23-2013; Ord. 2019-19, 8-27-2019)
CHAPTER 5
TREE PRESERVATION
SECTION:
7-5-1:    Definitions
7-5-2:    Urban Forest Inventory; Urban Forest Management Plan
7-5-3:    Tree Planting
7-5-4:    Tree Removal
7-5-5:    Damage To Trees
7-5-6:    Tree Transplantation
7-5-7:    Tree Replacement
7-5-8:    Legacy Trees
7-5-9:    Site Development On Private Property
7-5-10: Conservation Areas/Easements
7-5-11: Tree Permits
7-5-12:   Civil Enforcement
7-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter:
                                   Any person who is licensed or certified in

                                   Arboriculture or any other substantially
                                   similar organization.
COMMISSION:                        The Forestry Commission of the village.
                                   An area on the ground extending out from the
CRITICAL ROOT ZONE:                trunk of the tree in all directions a
                                   distance of at least one foot (1') for every
                                   inch (1") DBH.
                                   The diameter of the trunk of the tree
DIAMETER AT BREAST HEIGHT ("DBH"): measured in inches at a point 4.5 feet above
                                   ground line.
SUPERINTENDENT:                    The Superintendent of Public Works for the
                                   village.
                                   Any tree located on public property within
                                   the corporate boundaries of the village (i)
LEGACY TREE:                       having a DBH of eighteen inches (18") or
                                   more or (ii) as otherwise designated by
                                   ordinance.
                                   Any proposed change in the use or character
                                   of land, including but not limited to the
SITE DEVELOPMENT:                  construction or replacement of any structure
