                                   Grundy Counties, Illinois.
VILLAGE ARBORIST:                  Any arborist that is employed by the
                                   village.
(Ord. 2019-19, 8-27-2019)           
 
7-5-2:    URBAN FOREST INVENTORY; URBAN FOREST MANAGEMENT PLAN:
   A.   On or before January 1, 2020, the Superintendent shall conduct an Urban
Forest Inventory for the Village of Minooka, which inventory must be approved
and adopted by the corporate authorities of the village. Once the Urban Forest
Inventory has been completed and adopted by the corporate authorities of the
village, it shall be kept and maintained by the Superintendent. Thereafter, the
Superintendent shall update the Urban Forest Inventory of the village at least
annually, and shall submit the updated inventory to the corporate authorities
of the village for approval and adoption. The Urban Forest Inventory must
include an appraised value for each tree.
   B.   On or before January 1, 2021, the Commission shall recommend an Urban
Forest Management Plan for the Village of Minooka, which plan must be approved
and adopted by the corporate authorities of the village. Once the Urban Forest
Management Plan has been adopted by the village, the Commission shall review it
at least annually and make any recommendations and proposals for amendments of,
additions to, or deletions from said plan as it may determine to be necessary
from time to time.
   C.   The Urban Forest Management Plan:
      1.   Shall cover a period of at least five (5) years;
      2.   Shall be based upon guidelines published by the American National
Standards Institute from time to time; and
      3.   Must include, at a minimum, the following:
         a.   Tree selection guidelines (including a preferred species list, a
non-preferred species list, and a prohibited species (nuisance and invasive)
list); and
         b.   Tree diversity guidelines; and
         c.   Tree planting guidelines; and
         d.   Tree removal guidelines; and
         e.   Tree transplantation/translocation guidelines; and
         f.   Tree care and management guidelines; and
         g.   Budgetary and staffing guidelines; and
         h.   Template tree permit application materials. (Ord. 2019-19, 8-27-
2019)
7-5-3:    TREE PLANTING:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person who is not employed by the village
to plant any tree on any public property within the corporate boundaries of the
village without having first secured a tree permit authorizing such planting.
   B.   Every tree planted within the village must be planted in a manner that
is fully compliant with all applicable guidelines contained in the village's
Urban Forest Management Plan, as amended from time to time.
   C.   No tree permit shall be issued for any planting unless the applicant
submits and the village approves a three (3) year tree maintenance plan that
fully complies with all applicable guidelines of the village's Urban Forest
Management Plan, as amended from time to time.
   D.   Any person that plants a tree without a permit in violation of this
section shall be guilty of a business offense and fined an amount equal to:
      1.   Fifty dollars ($50.00); and
      2.   The actual costs incurred by the village in connection with the tree
so planted (whether for the purposes of removal, replanting, or remediation).
   Every tree so planted shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 2019-19, 8-
27-2019)
7-5-4:    TREE REMOVAL:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person who is not employed by the village
to remove any tree on any public property within the corporate boundaries of
the village without having first secured a tree permit authorizing such
removal.
   B.   Any tree removed pursuant to a tree permit issued by the village must
be removed in a manner that is fully compliant with all applicable guidelines
contained in the village's Urban Forest Management Plan, as amended from time
to time.
   C.   Any person that intentionally removes a tree without a tree permit in
violation of this section shall be guilty of a business offense and shall be
fined in an amount equal to:
      1.   The appraised value of the tree, as set out in the village's Urban
Forest Inventory, as amended from time to time; and
      2.   The actual costs incurred by the village to replace the tree in
compliance with Section
7-5-7 of this chapter.
   Every tree so removed shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 2019-19, 8-
27-2019)
7-5-5:    DAMAGE TO TREES:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to damage any tree located on any
public property within the corporate boundaries of the village. For the
purposes of this section, the word "damage" means any action that has the
direct and natural consequence of causing any permanent loss of function in a
tree, including without limitation: root compaction, root removal, girdling,
soil contamination, topping, canopy removal, bark removal, poisoning, improper
mulching, and any other action that results in the death or irreversible
decline of the tree.
   B.   Any person that damages any tree in violation of this section shall be
guilty of a business offense and shall be fined in an amount equal to:
      1.   The appraised value of the tree, as set out in the village's Urban
Forest Inventory, as amended from time to time; and
      2.   The actual costs incurred by the village to replace the tree in
compliance with Section
7-5-7 of this chapter or else to remediate the damage done.
   Every tree so damaged shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 2019-19, 8-
27-2019)
7-5-6:    TREE TRANSPLANTATION:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person who is not employed by the village
to transplant any tree on any public property within the corporate boundaries
of the village without having first secured a tree permit authorizing such
transplantation.
   B.   Any tree transplanted pursuant to a tree permit issued by the village
must be removed and replanted in a manner that is fully compliant with all
applicable guidelines contained in the village's Urban Forest Management Plan,
as amended from time to time.
   C.   No tree permit shall be issued for any transplantation unless the
applicant submits and the village approves a three (3) year tree maintenance
plan that fully complies with all applicable guidelines of the village's Urban
Forest Management Plan, as amended from time to time.
   D.    Any person that intentionally transplants a tree without a tree permit
in violation of this section shall be guilty of a business offense and shall be
fined in amount equal to:
      1.   The appraised value of the tree, as set out in the village's Urban
Forest Inventory, as amended from time to time; and
      2.   The actual costs incurred by the village to replace the tree in
compliance with Section
7-5-7 of this chapter.
   Every tree so transplanted shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 2019-
19, 8-27-2019)
7-5-7:    TREE REPLACEMENT:
   A.   Every tree selected to replace an existing tree located on any public
property within the corporate boundaries of the village shall be selected from
the village's preferred species list, as amended from time to time.
   B.   Every replacement tree required to be planted pursuant to this chapter
shall be planted in full compliance with Section
7-5-3 of this chapter. (Ord. 2019-19, 8-27-2019)
7-5-8:    LEGACY TREES:
   A.   The Superintendent shall keep a list, to be known as the "Legacy Tree
List," of every legacy tree in the Village of Minooka.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person other than an employee of the
village to remove, transplant, or damage any legacy tree without a tree permit
approved by a majority vote of corporate authorities of the village.
   C.    No tree permit shall be issued for any planting or transplanting of
any legacy tree unless the applicant submits and the village approves a three
(3) year tree maintenance plan that fully complies with all applicable
guidelines of the village's Urban Forest Management Plan, as amended from time
to time.
   D.   Any person that removes, transplants, or damages any legacy tree in
violation of this section shall be guilty of a business offense and shall be
fined in an amount equal to:
      1.   Five hundred dollars ($500.00); and
      2.   The appraised value of the tree, as set out in the village's Urban
Forest Inventory, as amended from time to time; and
      3.   The actual costs incurred by the village to replace the tree in
compliance with Section
7-5-7 of this chapter or else to remediate the damage done.
   Every legacy tree removed, transplanted, or damaged in violation of this
section shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 2019-19, 8-27-2019)
7-5-9:    SITE DEVELOPMENT ON PRIVATE PROPERTY:
   A.   Any person that wishes to engage in site development on any parcel of
private property in the village must request a site review by a village
arborist if:
      1.   Any work related to the proposed site development will encroach into
the critical root zone of any legacy tree; or
      2.   Any work related to the proposed site development will encroach into
the critical root zone of at least three (3) trees located on public property;
or
      3.   The person is so directed by the Superintendent.
   B.   Within five (5) business days after any person requests a site review,
a village arborist must conduct an inspection of the site in question and make
a determination whether the proposed site development is likely to have any
negative impact on any tree located on public property.
      1.   If a village arborist conducts a site inspection as required by this
section and determines that the proposed site development is unlikely to have
any negative impact on any tree located on the abutting public property, the
village arborist shall render his or her determination in writing to that
effect and deliver a copy of said determination to the person that requested
the site inspection. Thereafter, the site development may thereafter proceed
without any further approvals or actions under this chapter (though nothing in
this section is intended or shall be deemed to release any person from their
obligation to comply with any and all other applicable provisions of this Code
and the person shall still be held liable for any damage caused to any tree on
public property).
      2.   If a village arborist conducts such a site inspection as required by
this section and determines that the proposed site development is likely to
have a negative impact on any tree located on the abutting public property, the
village arborist shall render his or her determination in writing to that
effect and deliver a copy of said determination to the person that requested
the site inspection. Thereafter, the site development may not proceed unless
and until (i) the owner of the property in question submits a tree preservation
plan to the village and (ii) the village approves said tree preservation plan
and issues a tree permit authorizing the site development.
   C.   Every tree preservation plan required by this section shall be
submitted to the Public Works Department of the village, along with an
application for a tree permit, and shall be accompanied at a minimum by the
following:
      1.   A detailed description of the proposed site development, including a
list of any and all heavy machinery that is expected to be employed and copies
of any and all engineering plans or documents; and
      2.   A copy of the village arborist's written determination; and
      3.   A list of all protective measures that will be employed to prevent
or mitigate as much as possible any negative impact upon the tree(s) identified
in the village arborist's written determination.
   Every tree preservation plan so submitted must be developed in consultation
with a licensed or certified arborist and shall bear such arborist's signature
and certification. The village reserves the right to require that additional
protective measures be added to a tree preservation plan as a condition of
approval.
   D.   Any person that engages in site development on any parcel of private
property without securing a written determination from a village arborist in
violation of this section is guilty of a business offense and shall be fined in
an amount equal to fifty dollars ($50.00). In addition, to the extent that the
site development undertaken by any person liable under this Subsection C causes
any damage to any tree located on any parcel of public property, that person
shall also be liable for such damage as set forth in Section
7-5-5 of this chapter.
   E.   Any person that engages in site development on any parcel of private
property without receiving approval of a tree preservation plan and a tree
permit shall, if such approvals were required by this section, be guilty of a
business offense and shall be fined in an amount equal to one hundred and fifty
dollars ($150.00). In addition, to the extent that the site development
undertaken by any person liable under this Subsection D causes any damage to
any tree located on any parcel of public property, that person shall also be
liable for such damage as set forth in Section
7-5-5 of this chapter.
   F.   In the event that any person requests and receives approval of a tree
preservation plan and tree permit under this section, undertakes the approved
site development, and as a result causes any damage to any tree located on any
parcel of public property, that person shall not be guilty of any offense or
otherwise held liable for such damage unless the village proves that the person
failed to comply with any of the protective measures set out in the approved
tree preservation plan. If the village proves that the person failed to comply
with any of the protective measures set out in the tree preservation plan, the
person shall be liable for any and all damage caused, as set forth in Section
7-5-5 of this chapter. (Ord. 2019-19, 8-27-2019)
7-5-10: CONSERVATION AREAS/EASEMENTS:
   A.   For the purposes of this chapter, any area or parcel of property that
is or may be dedicated to the village for the purposes of conservation and/or
preservation shall be considered "public property" for the purposes of applying
this chapter to any trees located within any such area or parcel.
   B.    To the extent that any plat, agreement, or other legally-operative
document used to affect the dedication of a conservation area or easement to
the village (i.e. the dedication document) has restrictions or provisions that
conflict with or are more restrictive than the provisions of this chapter, the
terms and provisions of the dedication document shall control. (Ord. 2019-19,
8-27-2019)
7-5-11: TREE PERMITS:
   A.   Every applicant for a tree permit shall submit their request to the
Village Clerk on a form to be provided by the village.
   B.   Upon receipt of any application for a tree permit, the Village Clerk
shall, as soon thereafter as practicable, forward said application to the
Superintendent.
   C.    The Superintendent shall, with the assistance of the village
arborists, review the application and shall, within thirty (30) days after
receipt, make a final written determination either issuing or denying the tree
permit. However, if the Superintendent, in his or her sole discretion,
determines that additional information is needed in order to fully process the
application, he or she shall have the authority to request such additional
information from the applicant and the time for the Superintendent's final
written determination shall be extended until thirty (30) days after all
information so requested is received from the applicant.
   D.   In the event that the Superintendent refuses to issue any requested
tree permit, the applicant shall have the right to appeal said decision to the
Village Board. Any such appeal must be filed, if at all, in writing with the
Village Clerk within thirty (30) days of the Superintendent's final
determination. The decision of the Village Board on all appeals is and shall be
the final administrative decision of the village.
   E.   Every tree permit issued pursuant to this chapter shall be good for a
period of one (1) year from the date of issuance and shall expire if the work
authorized by the tree permit is not commenced within such one (1) year period.
   F.    Every tree permit issued pursuant to this chapter shall be subject to
any and all reasonable conditions and restrictions that the Superintendent (or
the Village Board, in the case of appeal) determines are necessary to ensure
compliance with all applicable guidelines contained in the village's Urban
Forest Management Plan. (Ord. 2019-19, 8-27-2019)
7-5-12: CIVIL ENFORCEMENT:
   A.   The Superintendent is, with the assistance of the Village Attorney,
authorized to take any action permitted under the constitution and laws of the
State of Illinois that he deems necessary to enforce the provisions of this
chapter, including but not limited to sending cease and desist letters, issuing
stop-work orders, and filing lawsuits.
   Every violation of this chapter may be enforced, in the Superintendent's
discretion, by administrative proceedings before the village's code hearing
department or else in any manner available to the village in equity or at law.
(Ord. 2019-19, 8-27-2019)
TITLE 8
POLICE REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
POLICE DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
8-1-1: Members, Duties
8-1-2: Special Police Officers
8-1-3: Call For Assistance
8-1-1: MEMBERS, DUTIES:
   A.   The village president and members of the board of trustees, police
chief and any police officer or special police officer appointed at any time by
authority of the village president shall constitute the police department of
the village. It shall be the duty of each member of the police force to enforce
all village ordinances relating to the preservation of the peace, health, good
order and quiet of the village and to prosecute all violations of all village
ordinances. (1904 Code § 20.1; amd. 1977 Code)
   B.   There is hereby established the position of one deputy chief in the
village of Minooka. The deputy chief position shall be an exempt rank
immediately below that of chief. The deputy chief may be appointed from any
rank of sworn, full time officers of the village's police department, but must
have at least five (5) years of full time service as a police officer in said
department. A deputy chief shall serve at the discretion of the chief and, if
removed from the position, shall revert to the rank held immediately prior to
appointment to the deputy chief position. (Ord. 2002-04, 2-26-2002)
   C.   There is hereby established the position of police department
administrator in the village of Minooka. The police department administrator
position shall be an exempt rank immediately below that of chief. The police
department administrator shall be an appointment by the chief of police, and
may be removed from office in accordance with the personnel policy manual. The
compensation of the police department administrator shall be determined from
time to time by the board of trustees. The police department administrator
shall assist the chief of police in the administration and operation of the
police department, and shall perform such other law and nonlaw enforcement
duties as may be directed from time to time by the chief of police. (Ord. 2006-
35, 9-26-2006)
   D.   All part time police officers shall serve for such term and on such
conditions as may be designated by the terms of such appointment, but the
number of hours a part time officer may work within a calendar year is
restricted. Appointments may be revoked at any time, and part time police
officers shall meet the following requirements:
      1.   Successfully completed any training mandated by the Illinois law
enforcement training and standards board.
      2.   At least twenty one (21) years of age.
      3.   A high school graduate or equivalent.
      4.   Have a current and valid motor vehicle operator's license.
      5.   Not convicted of a felony or any other crime involving moral
turpitude.
      6.   Submit fingerprints to the chief of police for a formal background
check by the Illinois state police and federal bureau of investigation, and
pass said background check. (Ord. 2012-13, 6-26-2012)
8-1-2: SPECIAL POLICE OFFICERS:
The board of trustees may, from time to time, appoint as many police officers
and special police officers as they may deem necessary, who shall hold their
offices during the pleasure of the village board, but not to exceed the
municipal year in which they are appointed. (1904 Code § 6.12; amd. 1977 Code)
8-1-3: CALL FOR ASSISTANCE:
Any police officer of the village may call to his assistance any person over
the age of twenty one (21) years to assist him in the execution of any legal
process, or in making an arrest of any offender against the ordinances of the
village or the laws of the state of Illinois, or to assist in the preservation
of the public peace, and if such person so summoned neglects or refuses to aid
and assist in taking, arresting or securing any person against whom there may
have been issued any civil or criminal process, or neglects or refuses to aid
and assist in retaking or securing who, after having been arrested or confined,
may have escaped from any such arrest or imprisonment, or neglects or refuses
to aid and assist in preventing any breach of the peace or the commission of
any criminal offense, being thereto lawfully required by any police officer of
the village concerned in the administration of justice, shall be deemed guilty
of a misdemeanor. (1904 Code § 6.12; amd. 1977 Code)
CHAPTER 2
GENERAL OFFENSES
SECTION:
8-2-1: Disorderly Conduct
8-2-2: Damaging Property
8-2-3: Weapons, Discharging
8-2-4: Playing Ball In Streets
8-2-5: Posting Handbills, Injuring Property
8-2-6: Public Indecency
8-2-7: Fireworks
8-2-8: Trespass
8-2-9: Cannabis, Synthetic Cannabis, And Drug Paraphernalia
8-2-1: DISORDERLY CONDUCT:
   A.   Enumerated: A person commits disorderly conduct when he knowingly:
      1.   Does any act in such unreasonable manner as to alarm or disturb
another and to provoke a breach of the peace; or
      2.   While acting as a collection agency as defined in the "collection
agency act" or as an employee of such collection agency, and while attempting
to collect an alleged debt, makes a telephone call to the alleged debtor which
is designed to harass, annoy or intimidate the alleged debtor; or
      3.   Transmits or causes to be transmitted a false report to the
department of public health under the nursing home care act; or
      4.   Transmits or causes to be transmitted a false report under article
II of "an act in relation to victims of violence and abuse", approved September
16, 1984, as amended; or
      5.   Knowingly does or makes any unreasonable or offensive act,
utterance, gesture, or display that under the circumstances creates a clear and
present danger of a breach of peace or imminent threat of violence; or
      6.   Knowingly fails to obey a lawful order of dispersal by a person
known to be a peace officer under circumstances under which three (3) or more
persons are committing acts of disorderly conduct in the immediate vicinity
that are likely to cause substantial harm or serious inconvenience, annoyance,
or alarm; or
      7.   Knowingly assembles with three (3) or more persons for the purpose
of using force or violence to disturb the public peace; or
      8.   Wilfully makes or assists in the making of any noise or diversion
that disturbs or tends to disturb the peace or good order of a school session
or class while on public or private grounds adjacent to any building in which a
school or any class is in session; or
      9.   Engages in fighting, threatening or tumultuous behavior upon any
school property, public or private; or
      10. Wilfully makes or assists in the making of any loud, unnecessary or
unusual noise or noises, caused by any horn, bell, radio, loudspeaker, vehicle,
motorcycle, dirt bike, or other such instrument, which are of such character,
intensity and duration as to annoy, disturb, injure or endanger the comfort,
repose, health, peace or safety of others within the village. (Ord. 2007-38, 7-
24-2007)
   B.   Penalty: In addition to all other remedies, any person who violates,
disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with any provision of this
section shall be sentenced as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each offense. (Ord. 2011-29, 12-20-2011)
8-2-2: DAMAGING PROPERTY:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully, maliciously or
negligently break, deface, injure or destroy any property within the village,
whether such property is owned by the state, county, village or any other
governmental body, or owned by any private person. Any person violating this
provision shall be punished as provided in section 1-4-1 of this code. (1977
Code)
   B.   Any person who shall wantonly break the glass in any streetlamp or
injure the burner thereof, or any part, wire or support thereof, or who shall,
without proper authority from the village president and board of trustees,
either light or extinguish the burner of any lamp in the village, shall be
deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. (1904 Code § 14.1)
8-2-3: WEAPONS, DISCHARGING:
No person shall fire or discharge any gun, cannon, musket, rifle, fowling
piece, pistol, air gun or firearm of any description, or release or fire any
projecting type instrument such as an arrow within the limits of the village,
except in cases of necessity or in the performance of a public act or lawful
duty, without first having obtained permission from the village president for
that purpose. (Ord. 1985-19, 10-28-1985)
8-2-4: PLAYING BALL IN STREETS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to play ball, raise or fly any kite or ride
any bike, skateboard and roller skates in any part of the village devoted to
business purposes, or in any street, alley or other public place in any portion
of the village, to the disturbance or annoyance of any citizen or person
passing along any such street, alley or other public place. (1904 Code § 22.13;
amd. 1997 Code)
8-2-5: POSTING HANDBILLS, INJURING PROPERTY:
It shall be unlawful for any person to post, paint, cut, write or otherwise
place any handbill, notice or any written or printed matter upon any bridge,
approach to a bridge, fence, wall, stone, post, tree, building or other public
place without the consent of the owner of said property, or to break any window
or in any manner to injure any building, fence, sidewalk or tree. (1904 Code §
6.9)
8-2-6: PUBLIC INDECENCY:
   A.   Public Indecency: A person commits the offense of public indecency if
they knowingly or intentionally, in a public place: 1) engage in sexual
intercourse; 2) engage in deviate sexual conduct; 3) appear in a state of
nudity; or 4) fondles the genitals of himself/herself or another person.
   B.   Definitions:
   NUDITY: The showing of the human male or female genitals, pubic area, female
breast with less than a full opaque covering of any part of the nipple, the
covered male genitals in a discernibly turgid state or that portion of the
buttocks which would be covered by a properly worn "thong" type bikini bottom.
   PUBLIC PLACE: Any location frequented by the public, or where the public is
present or likely to be present, or where a person may reasonably be expected
to be observed by members of the public. Public places include, but are not
limited to, streets, sidewalks, parks, beaches, business and commercial
establishments (whether for profit or not for profit and whether open to the
public at large or where entrance is limited by a cover charge or membership
requirement), hotels, motels, restaurants, nightclubs, country clubs, cabarets,
and meeting facilities utilized by religious, social, fraternal or similar
organizations. Premises used solely as a private residence, whether permanent
or temporary in nature, shall not be deemed a public place. Public place shall
not include enclosed single sex public restrooms, enclosed single sex
functional showers, locker and/or dressing room facilities, enclosed motel
rooms and hotel rooms designed and intended for sleeping accommodations,
doctors' offices, churches, synagogues or similar places when used for
circumcisions, baptisms or similar ceremonies, portions of hospitals and
similar places in which nudity or exposure is necessarily and customarily
expected outside of the home; nor shall it include a person appearing in a
state of nudity as a model in a class operated by: 1) a proprietary school
licensed by the state; a college, junior college or university supported
entirely or partly by taxation; or 2) a private college or university which
maintains and operates educational programs in which credits are transferable
to a college, junior college or university supported entirely or partly by
taxation or an accredited private college. (Ord. 1999-03, 3-9-1999)
   C.   Violation; Penalty:
      1.   In addition to all other remedies, a person who violates, disobeys,
omits, neglects or refuses to comply with any provision of this section shall
be sentenced as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each offense and may be enjoined from continuing the
conduct determined to be public indecency.
      2.   A person who knowingly or intentionally encourages or facilitates
another person's commission of the offense of public indecency shall be deemed
to have committed the offense itself.
      3.   A club, restaurant, theater or other place where violations of this
section occur shall be deemed a public nuisance which shall be subject to
abatement. (Ord. 2011-29, 12-20-2011)
   D.   Interpretation:
      1.   This section is patterned after Indiana public indecency statute
upheld by the United States supreme court in Barnes v. Glen Theatre, Inc., 501
U.S. 560, 111 S.Ct. 2456 (1991). It is the intent of the village that this
section be interpreted in the same manner as said statute.
      2.   It is the intent of the village that the definition of "public
place" set forth above shall be interpreted to be no more broad than the
definition of public place set forth in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-
9 as upheld by the Illinois supreme court in People v. Garrison, 82 Ill.2d 444,
412 N.E.2d 483 (1980). (Ord. 1999-03, 3-9-1999)
8-2-7: FIREWORKS:
   A.   Nuisance: It shall be unlawful and a nuisance for any person, firm,
copartnership or corporation to knowingly possess, offer for sale, sell at
retail, or use or explode any fireworks; provided, however, that the president
and village board may issue a permit for pyrotechnical and consumer displays.
   B.   Definitions:
   FIREWORKS: Any explosive composition or any substance or combination of
substances, or article prepared for the purpose of producing a visible or
audible effect of a temporary exhibitional nature by explosion, combustion,
deflagration or detonation, and shall include blank cartridges, toy cannons in
which explosives are used, the type of balloons which require fire underneath
to propel the same, firecrackers, torpedoes, skyrockets, roman candles, bombs
or other fireworks of like construction and any fireworks containing any
explosive compound, or any tablets or other device containing any explosive
substance, or containing combustible substances producing visual effects, or
any tablets or other device containing any explosive substance, or containing
combustible substances producing visual effects, and shall include the terms
"consumer fireworks", "display fireworks", and "flame effects" as defined in
the fireworks use act, 425 Illinois Compiled Statutes 35/1.
      The term "fireworks" shall not include snake or glowworm pellets; smoke
devices; sparklers; trick noisemakers known as "party poppers", "booby traps",
"snappers", "trick matches", "cigarette loads" and "auto burglar alarms"; toy
pistols, toy canes, toy guns, or other devices in which paper or plastic caps
containing twenty five hundredths (0.25) grain or less of explosive compound
are used, provided they are so constructed that the hand cannot come in contact
with the cap when in place for the explosion; and toy pistol paper or plastic
caps which contain less than twenty hundredths (0.20) grain of explosive
mixture; the sale and use of which shall be permitted at all times.
   C.   Permits:
      1.   Pyrotechnic Displays:
         a.   Each pyrotechnic display shall be conducted by a licensed lead
pyrotechnic operator. Applications for a pyrotechnic display permit shall be
made in writing at least fifteen (15) days in advance of the date of the
pyrotechnic display. No pyrotechnic display permit shall be transferable.
         b.   Permits shall be signed by the chief of the fire department
providing fire protection to the area of display, or his or her designee, and
must identify the lead pyrotechnic operator.
         c.   The applicant seeking the pyrotechnic display permit must provide
proof of liability insurance in a sum not less than one million dollars
($1,000,000.00), naming the village of Minooka as an additional insured, to
satisfy claims for damages to property or personal injuries arising out of any
act or omission on the part of such person, firm, or corporation or any agent
or employee thereof.
         d.   A permit shall be issued only after the chief of the fire
department providing fire protection coverage to the area of display, or his or
her designee, has inspected the site and determined that the display can be
performed in full compliance with the rules adopted by the state fire marshal
and that the display shall not be hazardous to property or endanger any person
or persons. Nothing in this section shall prohibit the village from adopting
more stringent rules.
      2.   Consumer Displays:
         a.   Each consumer display shall be handled by a competent individual
who has received training from a consumer fireworks training class approved by
the office of the state fire marshal. Applications for consumer display permits
shall be made in writing at least fifteen (15) days in advance of the date of
the display. No consumer displays permit shall be transferable.
         b.   Permits may be granted hereunder to any adult individual applying
for a permit who provides proof that he or she has received the requisite
training. The village is authorized to conduct a criminal background check of
the applicant as a condition of issuing a permit at the applicant's expense.
         c.   A permit shall be issued only after inspection of the display
site by the fire chief providing fire protection coverage to the area of
display, or his or her designee, to determine that the display is in full
compliance with the rules adopted by the state fire marshal. Nothing in this
section shall prohibit the village from adopting more stringent rules.
   D.   Exceptions: Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit any
of the following:
      1.   The sale at wholesale of any fireworks for supervised displays by
any approved resident manufacturer, wholesaler, dealer, or jobber in accordance
with regulations of the U.S. bureau of alcohol, tobacco and firearms (see title
27, code of federal regulations, subchapter C) and the U.S. department of
transportation;
      2.   The manufacture, transportation or storage of fireworks at a
manufacturing facility, and the testing of fireworks under the direction of its
manufacturer provided permission for such testing has been obtained from the
village;
      3.   The sale, transportation, handling or use of industrial pyrotechnic
devices or fireworks such as railroad torpedoes, fuses, automotive,
aeronautical and marine flares and smoke signals;
      4.   The manufacture, storage or use of signals or fuses necessary for
the safe operation of railroads, trucks, aircraft, or other instrumentalities
of transportation;
      5.   The sale and use of blank cartridges for use in a show or theater,
for signal or ceremonial purposes, in athletics or sports, or legal power
tools;
      6.   The transportation, handling, or use of pyrotechnic devices by the
armed forces of the United States;
      7.   The use of pyrotechnics in training by the fire service, law
enforcement or similar government agencies; and
      8.   Fireworks devices distributed to farmers, ranchers, or growers
through a wildlife management program administered by the U.S. department of
the interior (or by equivalent state or local government agencies); and such
distribution is in response to a written application describing the wildlife
management problem that requires use of such devices, is of a quantity no
greater than required to control the problem described, and is where other
means of control is unavailable or inadequate.
   E.   Owner Of Real Property: If the owner of real property on which any of
the prohibited activities as set forth in this section is present while the
prohibited activity or activities occurs, said owner shall also be deemed to
have committed an offense. (Ord. 2007-29, 6-26-2007)
   F.   Penalty: In addition to all other remedies, any person, firm,
copartnership or corporation who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses
to comply with any of the provisions of this section shall be sentenced as
provided in section 1-4-1 of this Code for each offense. (Ord. 2011-29, 12-20-
2011)
8-2-8: TRESPASS:
   A.   Violation: A person commits the offense of trespass when knowingly or
intentionally:
      1.   Enters upon the land of another, including public property, when the
person, prior to such entry, receives notice that such entry is forbidden; or
      2.   Remains upon the land of another, including public property, after
receiving notice to depart; or
      3.   Enters upon the land of another, including public property, and
remains thereon with a malicious and mischievous intent after receiving notice
to depart.
   B.   Notice: A person has received notice within the meaning of subsection A
of this section if the person has been notified personally, either orally by an
official in the performance of his or her official duties or by an owner or
occupant, or in writing, including a valid court order, or if a printed or
written notice forbidding such entry has been conspicuously posted or exhibited
at the main entrance to such property or the forbidden part thereof.
   C.   Exception: This section does not prohibit a person from entering upon
the land of another, including public property, for emergency purposes or to a
peace officer or other official of a unit of government in the performance of
his or her official duties.
   D.   Definitions: For purposes of this section:
   EMERGENCY: A condition or circumstance in which an individual is or is
reasonably believed by the person to be in imminent danger of serious bodily
harm or in which property is or is reasonably believed to be in imminent danger
of damage or destruction.
   PUBLIC PROPERTY: Property owned by the Village or the government or one of
its agencies, divisions, or entities, including, but not limited to, parks,
playgrounds, streets, sidewalks, schools, libraries, trails, ponds, lakes,
parkways or parking areas and other property regularly used by the general
public, as opposed to land held by an individual, a corporation or private
entity trust for the benefit of the owners (private property). (Ord. 2011-06,
2-22-2011)
   E.   Penalty: In addition to all other remedies, every person who violates,
disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with this section shall be
sentenced as provided in section 1-4-1 of this Code for each offense. (Ord.
2011-29, 12-20-2011)
8-2-9: CANNABIS, SYNTHETIC CANNABIS, AND DRUG PARAPHERNALIA:
   A.   Definitions: For purposes of this section, the following definitions
shall apply:
   CANNABIS: Shall have the same meaning ascribed to it in the Illinois
Cannabis Control Act (720 ILCS 550/3), as amended from time to time.
   CONTROLLED SUBSTANCE:
         1.   A drug, substance, or immediate precursor in the schedules of
article II of 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 570/201 et seq., or
         2.   A drug or other substance, or immediate precursor, designated as
a controlled substance by the department through administrative rule, and
includes, but is not limited to, the following:
         2,5-dimethoxy-4-(n)-propylthio-phenethylamine
         3-fluoromethcathinone

yl)phenol), where side chain n=5; and homologues where side chain n=4, 6, or 7)
         CP 47,497 and its C6, C8 and C9 homologs (2- [1R,3S)-3-
hydroxycyclohexyl]-5-(2-methyloctan-2-yl)phenol)

methyloctan-2-yl)-6a,7,10,10a- tetrahydrobenzo[c]chromen-1-ol)
         JWH-015 ((2-methyl-1-propyl-1H-indol-3-yl)-1- naphthalenyl-methanone)
         JWH-018 (1-Pentyl-3-(1-naphthoyl)indole)

         JWH-081 (4-methoxynaphthalen-1-yl-(1-pentylindol- 3-yl)methanone)

         Mephedrone (4-Methylmethcathinone)
         Methylone (3,4-Methylenedioxymethcathinone)
         RCS-8, BTW-8 and SR-18 (1-(2-cyclohexylethyl)-3- (2-
methoxyphenylacetyl)indole)
         Any compound structurally derived from 3-(1- naphthoyl)indole or 1H-
indol-3-yl-(1-naphthyl)methane by substitution at the nitrogen atom of the
indole ring by alkyl, haloalkyl, alkenyl, cycloalkylmethyl, cycloalkylethyl or
2-(4- morpholinyl)ethyl whether or not further substituted in the indole ring
to any extent, whether or not substituted in the naphthyl ring to any extent
         Any compound structurally derived from 3-(1- naphthoyl)pyrrole by
substitution at the nitrogen atom of the pyrrole ring by alkyl, haloalkyl,
alkenyl, cycloalkylmethyl, cycloalkylethyl or 2-(4-morpholinyl)ethyl, whether
or not further substituted in the pyrrole ring to any extent, whether or not
substituted in the naphthyl ring to any extent
         Any compound structurally derived from 1-(1- naphthylmethyl)indene by
substitution at the 3-position of the indene ring by alkyl, haloalkyl, alkenyl,
cycloalkylmethyl, cycloalkylethyl or 2- (4-morpholinyl)ethyl whether or not
further substituted in the indene ring to any extent, whether or not
substituted in the naphthyl ring to any extent
         Any compound structurally derived from 3- phenylacetylindole by
substitution at the nitrogen atom of the indole ring with alkyl, haloalkyl,
alkenyl, cycloalkylmethyl, cycloalkylethyl or 2- (4-morpholinyl)ethyl, whether
or not further substituted in the indole ring to any extent, whether or not
substituted in the phenyl ring to any extent
         Any compound structurally derived from 2-(3- hydroxycyclohexyl)phenol
by substitution at the 5-position of the phenolic ring by alkyl, haloalkyl,
alkenyl, cycloalkylmethyl, cycloalkylethyl or 2-(4-morpholinyl)ethyl, whether
or not substituted in the cyclohexyl ring to any extent
   CONTROLLED SUBSTANCE ANALOG: A substance:
      1.   The chemical structure of which is substantially similar to the
chemical structure of a controlled substance in schedule I or II;
      2.   Which has a stimulant, depressant, or hallucinogenic effect on the
central nervous system that is substantially similar to or greater than the
stimulant, depressant, or hallucinogenic effect on the central nervous system
of a controlled substance in schedule I or II; or
      3.   With respect to a particular person, which such person represents or
intends to have a stimulant, depressant, or hallucinogenic effect on the
central nervous system that is substantially similar to or greater than the
stimulant, depressant, or hallucinogenic effect on the central nervous system
of a controlled substance in schedule I or II.
   DRUG PARAPHERNALIA: All equipment, products and materials of any kind, other
than methamphetamine manufacturing materials as defined in 720 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 646/10, the methamphetamine control and community protection
act, which are intended to be used unlawfully in planting, propagating,
cultivating, growing, harvesting, manufacturing, compounding, converting,
producing, processing, preparing, testing, analyzing, packaging, repackaging,
storing, containing, concealing, injecting, ingesting, inhaling or otherwise
introducing into the human body cannabis or a controlled substance in violation
of 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 550/1 et seq., the cannabis control act; 720
Illinois Compiled Statutes 570/100 et seq., the Illinois controlled substances
act; or 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 646/1 et seq., the methamphetamine
control and community protection act. It includes, but is not limited to:
      1.   Kits intended to be used unlawfully in manufacturing, compounding,
converting, producing, processing or preparing cannabis or a controlled
substance;
      2.   Isomerization devices intended to be used unlawfully in increasing
the potency of any species of plant which is cannabis or a controlled
substance;
      3.   Testing equipment intended to be used unlawfully in a private home
for identifying or in analyzing the strength, effectiveness or purity of
cannabis or controlled substances;
      4.   Diluents and adulterants intended to be used unlawfully for cutting
cannabis or a controlled substance by private persons;
      5.   Objects intended to be used unlawfully in ingesting, inhaling, or
otherwise introducing cannabis, synthetic cannabis, cocaine, hashish, or
hashish oil into the human body including, where applicable, the following
items:
         a.   Water pipes;
         b.   Carburetion tubes and devices;
         c.   Smoking and carburetion masks;
         d.   Miniature cocaine spoons and cocaine vials;
         e.   Carburetor pipes;
         f.   Electric pipes;
         g.   Air driven pipes;
         h.   Chillums;
         i.   Bongs;
         j.   Ice pipes or chillers; or
      6.   Any item whose purpose, as announced or described by the seller, is
for use in violation of this section.
   SYNTHETIC CANNABIS: An herbal and chemical product, whether described as
tobacco, herbs, incense, spice, or any blend thereof, regardless of whether the
substance is marketed for the purpose of being smoked, which mimics the effects
of the active ingredient in cannabis and tetrahydrocannabinol (THC), and
contains a cannabinoids receptor agonist as follows:
         CP 55,940 (2-[(1R,2R,5R)-5-hydroxy-2-(3- hydroxypropyl) cyclohexyl]-5-
(2-methyloctan-2-yl)phenol)
         HU-308 ([(1R,2R,5R)-2-[2,6-dimethoxy-4-(2- methyloctan-2-yl)phenyl]-
7,7-dimethyl-4-bicyclo[3.1.1]hept-3- enyl]methanol)
         HU-331 ((3-hydroxy-2-[(1R,6R)-3-methyl-6-(1- methylethenyl)-2-
cyclohexen-1-yl]-5-pentyl-2,5-cyclohexadiene- 1,4-dione)
         JWH-007 (1-pentyl-2-methyl-3-(1-naphthoyl)indole)
         JWH-019 (1-hexyl-3-(naphthalen-1-oyl)indole)
         JWH-073 (naphthalen-1-yl-(1-butylindol-3- yl)methanone)
         JWH-098 (4-methoxynaphthalen-1-yl-(1-pentyl-2- methylindol-3-
yl)methanone)
         JWH-164 (7-methoxynaphthalen-1-yl-(1-pentylindol- 3-yl)methanone)
         JWH-200 (1-(2-morpholin-4-ylethyl)indol-3-yl)- naphthalen-1-
ylmethanone)
         JWH-203 (2-(2-chlorophenyl)-1-(1-pentylindol-3- yl)ethanone)
         JWH-210 (4-ethylnaphthalen-1-yl-(1-pentylindol-3- yl)methanone)
         JWH-250 (1-pentyl-3-(2-methoxyphenylacetyl)indole)
         JWH-251 (1-pentyl-3-(2-methylphenylacetyl)indole)
         JWH-398 (1-pentyl-3-(4-chloro-1-naphthoyl)indole)
         RCS-4 ((4-methoxyphenyl)(1-pentyl-1H-indol-3- yl)methanone)
         RCS-8 (1-(1-(2-cyclohexylethyl)-1H-indol-3-yl)-2- (2-
methoxyphenyl)ethanone)
         WIN 55,212-2 ((R)-(+)-[2,3-Dihydro-5-methyl-3-(4- morpholinylmethyl)
pyrrolo[1,2,3-de)-1,4-benzoxazin-6-yl]-1- nepthalenylmethanone)
         Street names for synthetic cannabis may include, but are not limited
to, the following:
         Black mamba strawberry
         Black mamba tangerine
         Black mamba vanilla

   B.   Exceptions: This section shall not apply to any person who may, under
federal or state law, possess, manufacture, distribute, dispense, or ingest the
substances regulated by this section. Furthermore, if a violation is a felony,
it shall be prosecuted under appropriate federal and/or state law and not this
section.
   C.   Synthetic Cannabis And Controlled Substance:
      1.   Beginning on January 1, 2012, it shall be unlawful for any person to
sell, offer to sell, deliver, barter, give away, gift, or publicly display for
sale or otherwise transfer any product substance containing synthetic cannabis,
controlled substance, or controlled substance analog.
      2.   Beginning on January 1, 2012, it shall be unlawful for any person to
knowingly possess or ingest any substance containing synthetic cannabis,
controlled substance, or controlled substance analog. (Ord. 2011-24, 11-22-
2011)
   D.   Possession Of Cannabis:
      1.   Except as provided in the Cannabis Regulation and Tax Act (410 ILCS
705/1-1, et seq.), as amended; the Industrial Hemp Act (505 ILCS 89/1, et
seq.), as amended; or any other state or federal law, as amended, permitting
the cultivation, production, manufacture, sale, purchase, delivery, possession,
consumption, and/or use of cannabis, it shall be unlawful for any person to
knowingly possess not more than ten grams (10 g) of cannabis.
      2.   Except as provided in the Cannabis Regulation and Tax Act (410 ILCS
705/1-1, et seq.), as amended,; the Industrial Hemp Act (505 ILCS 89/1, et
seq.), as amended; or any other state or federal law, as amended, permitting
the cultivation, production, manufacture, sale, purchase, delivery, possession,
consumption, and/or use of cannabis, it shall be unlawful for any person to
knowingly possess more than ten grams (10 g) but not more than thirty grams (30
g) of cannabis.
   E.   Possession Of Drug Paraphernalia: Except as provided in the Cannabis
Regulation and Tax Act (410 ILCS 705/1-1, et seq.), as amended; the Industrial
Hemp Act (505 ILCS 89/1, et seq.), as amended; or any other state or federal
law, as amended, permitting the cultivation, production, manufacture, sale,
purchase, delivery, possession, consumption, and/or use of cannabis, it shall
be unlawful for any person to knowingly possess an item of drug paraphernalia
with the intent to use it in ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing
cannabis, synthetic cannabis, or a controlled substance into the human body, or
in preparing cannabis, synthetic cannabis, or a controlled substance for that
use.
   F.   Penalty:
      1.   A person convicted of violating subsection C1 of this section shall
be fined not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) and not more than as
provided by section 1-4-1 of this code for each offense.
      2.   A person convicted of violating subsection C2 of this section shall
be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) and not more than as
provided by section 1-4-1 of this code for each offense.
      3.   A person convicted of violating subsection D1 of this section shall
be fined not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00).
      4.   A person convicted of violating subsection D2 of this section shall
be fined not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) and not more than as
provided by section 1-4-1 of this code for each offense.
      5.   A person convicted of violating subsection E of this section shall
be fined as follows:
         a.   When the drug paraphernalia is seized alone or during a violation
of subsection (a) of section 4 of the cannabis control act (as amended by
Public Act 099-0697), the fine for possession of such drug paraphernalia shall
be two hundred dollars ($200.00).
         b.   Except as provided in subsection F5a of this section, the fine
shall be not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) and not more than as
provided by section 1-4-1 of this code for each offense. (Ord. 2011-24, 11-22-
2011; amd Ord. 2016-31, 9-21-2016; Ord. 2020-14, 4-28-2020)
CHAPTER 3
MINORS
SECTION:
8-3-1: Curfew
8-3-2: Smoking Materials (Rep. by Ord. 2004-08, 2-10-2004, eff. 5-1-2004)
8-3-3: Truancy Prohibited
8-3-1: CURFEW:
   A.   Loitering Of Minors: It is unlawful for a person less than seventeen
(17) years of age who has not been emancipated by court order (hereinafter
referred to as "minor") to be present at or upon any public assembly, building,
place, store or highway at the following times:
      Between one minute after twelve o'clock (12:01) A.M. and six o'clock (6:
00) A.M. Saturday;
      Between one minute after twelve o'clock (12:01) A.M. and six o'clock (6:
00) A.M. Sunday; and
      Between eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. on Sunday to Thursday, inclusive and
six o'clock (6:00) A.M. on the following day.
   B.   Defenses: It is a defense to a violation under subsection A of this
section that the minor engaged in the unlawful conduct while:
      1.   Accompanied by and supervised by the minor's parent, legal guardian
or other responsible companion at least eighteen (18) years of age approved by
a parent or legal guardian;
      2.   On the sidewalk abutting the minor's residence;
      3.   In a motor vehicle, train, or bus involved in interstate travel; or
      4.   Participating in, going to, or returning from, without any detour or
stop:
         a.   Employment which the laws of this state authorize a person less
than seventeen (17) years of age to perform;
         b.   A school recreational activity;
         c.   A religious event;
         d.   An emergency involving the protection of a person or property
from an imminent threat of serious bodily injury, loss of life, or substantial
damage, the resulting state calling for immediate action, and includes, but is
not limited to, a fire, a natural disaster, or automobile accident;
         e.   An activity involving the exercise of the minor's rights
protected under the first amendment to the United States constitution or
article 1, sections 3, 4 and 5 of the constitution of the state of Illinois, or
both; or
         f.   An activity conducted by a nonprofit or governmental entity that
provides recreation, education, training, or other care under the supervision
of one or more adults.
   C.   Parents: It is unlawful for a parent, legal guardian, custodian, or
other person to knowingly permit a person in his custody or control to violate
subsection A of this section; provided however that the defenses enumerated in
subsection B of this section do not apply.
   D.   Owners Of Amusement Places: It is unlawful for any person operating
places of amusement and entertainment, including, but not limited to, pool
halls, arcades and similar businesses, to permit any minors to enter or remain
in such places of amusement and entertainment during the hours prohibited under
this section; provided however that the defenses enumerated in subsection B of
this section do not apply.
   E.   Officer Investigation: A citation for violation of subsection A of this
section may be issued by a police officer if he reasonably believes that a
violation has occurred only after investigation and, based on any response and
other circumstances, none of the defenses enumerated in subsection B of this
section apply. (Ord. 2004-15, 4-27-2004)
8-3-2: SMOKING MATERIALS 1:
(Rep. by Ord. 2004-08, 2-10-2004, eff. 5-1-2004)
8-3-3: TRUANCY PROHIBITED:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of eighteen (18) who
is enrolled in grades one through twelve (12) who: 1) is required by law to
attend school and/or 2) is subject to the compulsory attendance requirements of
the Illinois school code and/or 3) is enrolled in a public, private or
parochial school within the corporate limits of the village, to absent himself
or herself from attendance at school without parental or school permission or
valid cause. Parental permission shall refer to and include permission obtained
from a parent, legal guardian, or other adult person standing in loco parentis
and having custody and control over such person under the age of eighteen (18)
years. Any person who shall so absent himself or herself shall be guilty of the
offenses of truancy and be subject to the penalties hereinafter set forth in
this section.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person who induces or attempts to induce
any child to be absent from school unlawfully, or who knowingly employs or
harbors, while school is in session, any child absent from school in violation
of this section.
   C.   A valid cause for absence from school shall include illness, observance
of a religious holiday, death in the immediate family, family emergency, and
shall include other situations beyond the control of the person so absenting
himself or herself from school as determined by the school district; provided
that parental permission for absence due to such cause is obtained, in writing,
from the parent and is submitted to the proper school authorities, according to
their regulations, within twenty four (24) hours after such absence, not
including weekends. (Ord. 2004-04, 1-27-2004)
   D.   In addition to all other remedies, any person who violates, disobeys,
omits, neglects or refuses to comply with any provision of subsection A or B of
this section shall be sentenced as provided in section 1-4-1 of this code, or
in lieu of a fine, complete a corresponding amount of public service work. If
it is the first offense, a violator may be assigned to work six (6) hours of
school assigned tasks in lieu of such fine. (Ord. 2011-29, 12-20-2011)
CHAPTER 4
ANIMAL CONTROL
SECTION:
